title: rapid and efficient conversion of integrationfree human induced pluripotent stem cell to gmpgrade culture condition
abstract: data suggest that clinical application of human induced pluripotent stem cell hipscs will be realized nonetheless clinical application will require hipscs that are free of exogenous dna and that can be manufactured through good manufacturing practice gmp optimally derivation of hipscs should be rapid and efficient in order to minimize manipulation reduce potential for accumulation of mutation and minimize financial cost previous study reported the use of modified synthetic mrna to reprogram fibroblast to a pluripotent state here we provide an optimized fully chemically defined and feederfree protocol for the derivation of hipscs using synthetic mrna the protocol result in derivation of fully reprogrammed hipsc line from adult dermal fibroblast in less than two week the hipsc line were successfully tested for their identity purity stability and safety at a gmp facility and cryopreserved to our knowledge a a proof of principle these are the first integrationfree ipscs line that were reproducibly generated through synthetic mrna reprogramming that could be putatively used for clinical purpose
label: Non-Cancer

title: hla variant related to primary sclerosing cholangitis influence rejection after liver transplantation
abstract: aim to investigate influence of human leukocyte antigen hla and killer immunoglobulinelike receptor kir genotype on risk of acute rejection ar after liver transplantation ltx method in this retrospective study we included adult donorrecipient pair with a minimum of mo followup after ltx for whom dna wa available from both donor and recipient clinical data all early complication including episode and severity of ar and graftpatient survival were registered the diagnosis of ar wa based on clinical biochemical and histological criterion all suspected episode of ar were biopsy confirmed key classical hla locus hlaa hlab hlac and hladrb were genotyped using sanger sequencing kir gene were genotyped using a novel real time pcr approach which allows for determination of the diploid copy number of each kir gene immunohistochemical staining for t cd b cd and natural killer nk cell cd and cd were performed on liver biopsy from different patient group primary sclerosing cholangitis psc primary biliary cirrhosis and nonautoimmune liver disease in each group with similar grade of ar result fourtyfour patient were transplanted on the basis of psc of them had ar v in the nonpsc group p no significant impact of donorrecipient matching for hla and kir genotype wa detected in the overall recipient population an increased risk of ar wa detected for hlab p or ci hlac p or ci and hladrb p or ci and a decreased risk for hladrb p or ci for hlab hlac and drb the association remained evident in a subgroup analysis of nonpsc recipient p p and p respectively in psc recipient corresponding p value were and for hlab hlac and drb respectively a dosage effect of ar prevalence according to the psc associated hla allele wa also notable in the total recipient population for hlab the frequency of ar wa in hlab homozygous recipient in heterozygous recipient and in recipient lacking hlab p the same wa observed for the hlac allele with ar in and in recipient being homozygous heterozygous and lacking hlac respectively p immunohistochemical analysis showed similar infiltration of t b and nk cell in biopsy with ar in all three group conclusion we found significant association between the pscassociated hlab hlac hladrb and hladrb allele and risk of ar in liver transplant recipient

title: diagnostic criterion and classification of mastocytosis in
abstract: mastocytosis is characterized by accumulation of pathologic mast cell in tissue most patient with mastocytosis experience mast cell activation symptom in response to various trigger the diagnosis of mastocytosis should be made from objective pathologic finding modern diagnostic criterion and classification of mastocytosis were proposed in by an international consensus group and formed the basis of the current world health organization who guideline which have been validated to correlate with prognosis and help selection of therapy in this article the who criterion for diagnosis and classification are summarized and practical aspect to avoid common pitfall in diagnostic workup are discussed
label: Non-Cancer

title: flow cytometry in mastocytosis utility a a diagnostic and prognostic tool
abstract: this article present information for the identification and characterization of mast cell from bone marrow and other tissue using multiparametric flow cytometry in addition it provides guideline for the application of this technique in the subclassification of systemic mastocytosis and assessment of the longterm prognosis of patient individually
label: Non-Cancer

title: mastocytosis immunophenotypical feature of the transformed mast cell are unique among hematopoietic cell
abstract: mastocytosis is a disease of bone marrow origin histologically characterized by compact tissue infiltrates of atypical mast cell never seen in reactive state most patient with mastocytosis have transformed mast cell carrying an activating point mutation at codon of kit and also show an elevated serum tryptase level in this article immunophenotypical feature of mast cell are described based on these feature mast cell are not closely related to other myeloid cell using the knowledge on aberrantly expressed antigen by mast cell the hematopathologist should be able to recognize the disease even in the presence of unusual morphologic finding or an associated hematologic nonmast cell lineage disease
label: Non-Cancer

title: pathology of extramedullary mastocytosis
abstract: mastocytosis encompasses a group of clinically and pathologically heterogeneous disorder most commonly involving the skin which typically take the form of urticaria pigmentosa mastocytosis may also involve other organ most often bone marrow followed by gastrointestinal tract liver spleen and lymph node the presence of extracutaneous involvement by mastocytosis is a major diagnostic criterion for systemic disease however mast cell infiltrates are often subtle in skin and extracutaneous organ and the histologic feature of mastocytosis at different anatomic site may be variable this article review the pathologic feature and clinical correlate of mastocytosis involving skin and other extramedullary site
label: Non-Cancer

title: the kit dv allele burden predicts survival in patient with mastocytosis and correlate with the who type of the disease
abstract: kit dv is present in a majority of patient with systemic mastocytosis sm we determined the kit dv allele burden by quantitative realtime pcr in bone marrow and peripheral blood of patient with mastocytosis kit dv wa detected in patient significant difference in the median allele burden were observed between disease subgroup cutaneous mastocytosis indolent sm smoldering sm aggressive sm and sm with associated hematologic nonmast cell lineage disease p the kit dv burden also correlated with serum tryptase r p but not with mast cell infiltration in bone marrow or mediator symptom moreover the allele burden wa of prognostic significance regarding survival p patient responding to cytoreductive therapy showed a significant decrease in kit dv p to conclude the kit dv burden correlate with the variant of mastocytosis predicts survival and is a valuable followup parameter in sm
label: Non-Cancer

title: the case of hnfbeta mutation with medullary cyst
abstract: we describe one case of longterm postnatal followup of hyperechoic fetal kidney related to hnfbeta mutation with cystic change over a year period in a female patient this diagnosis wa suspected on the basis of the renal u finding and wa confirmed by complementary genetic examination after birth cortical cyst were detected and at the age of medullary cyst were found that disappeared with time currently our patient display hyperechoic kidney with only cortical cyst this case report highlight the variability of u appearance in relation with hnfbeta genetic mutation
label: Non-Cancer
combined_text: the case of hnfbeta mutation with medullary cyst we describe one case of longterm postnatal followup of hyperechoic fetal kidney related to hnfbeta mutation with cystic change over a year period in a female patient this diagnosis wa suspected on the basis of the renal u finding and wa confirmed by complementary genetic examination after birth cortical cyst were detected and at the age of medullary cyst were found that disappeared with time currently our patient display hyperechoic kidney with only cortical cyst this case report highlight the variability of u appearance in relation with hnfbeta genetic mutation

title: leopard syndrome clinical dilemma in differential diagnosis of rasopathies
abstract: background diagnosis within rasopathies still represents a challenge nevertheless many effort have been made by clinician to identify specific clinical feature which might help in differentiating one disorder from another here we describe a child initially diagnosed with neurofibromatosisnoonan syndrome the followup of the proband the clinical evaluation of his father together with a genebygene testing approach led u to the proper diagnosis case presentation we report a yearold male with multiple cafeaulait macule several lentigo and dysmorphic feature that suggest noonan syndrome initially diagnosed with neurofibromatosisnoonan syndrome however after a few year of clinical and ophthalmological followup the absence of typical feature of neurofibromatosis type and the lack of nf mutation led u to reconsider the original diagnosis a new examination of the patient and his similarly affected father who wa initially referred a healthy led u to suspect leopard syndrome the diagnosis wa then confirmed by the occurrence in both patient of a heterozygous mutation c c t pthrmet of ptpn subsequently the proband wa also found to have type arnoldchiari malformation in association with syringomyelia conclusion our experience suggests that differential clinical diagnosis among rasopathies remains ambiguous and raise doubt on the current diagnostic clinical criterion in some case genetic test represent the only conclusive proof for a correct diagnosis and consequently for establishing individual prognosis and providing adequate followup thus molecular testing represents an essential tool in differential diagnosis of rasophaties this view is further strengthened by the increasing accessibility of new sequencing techniquesfinally to our knowledge the described case represents the third report of the occurrence of arnold chiari malformation and the second description of syringomyelia with leopard syndrome
label: Non-Cancer

title: rare and lowfrequency coding variant in cxcr and other gene are associated with hematological trait
abstract: hematological trait are important clinical parameter to test the effect of rare and lowfrequency coding variant on hematological trait we analyzed hemoglobin concentration hematocrit level white blood cell wbc count and platelet count in individual genotyped on an exome array we identified several missense variant in cxcr associated with reduced wbc count genebased p x in a separate familybased resequencing study we identified a cxcr frameshift mutation in a pedigree with congenital neutropenia that abolished ligandinduced cxcr signal transduction and chemotaxis we also identified missense or splicesite variant in key hematopoiesis regulator epo tfr hbb tubb and shb associated with blood cell trait finally we were able to detect association between a rare somatic jak mutation encoding pvalphe and platelet count p x a well a hemoglobin concentration p hematocrit level p x and wbc count p x in conclusion exome array complement genomewide association study in identifying new variant that contribute to complex human trait
label: Non-Cancer

title: new molecular diagnostic kit to assess ychromosome deletion in the japanese population
abstract: objective deletion in the azoospermia factor region are the most common known molecular genetic cause of human male infertility involving spermatogenetic failure testing for these deletion in japanese dna sample using conventional sequencetagged site probe occasionally lead to considerable nonspecific or faint product in the japanese population the aim of the present study wa to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of a newly developed kit for the detection of azoospermia factor microdeletions in the japanese population method sequencetagged site probe were reselected and the luminex suspension array assay wa carried out validation wa retrospectively carried out with dna sequence with known microdeletions which were divided into four category result category deletion that corresponded to the conventional classification of azoospermia factor deletion were present in men which can result in intrachromosomal homologous recombination kit data confirmed the presence of deletion of this type in dna sequence known to harbor the azoospermia factor deletion category deletion involved cytogenetic abnormality in men whereas category deletion in men were atypical classification including the grgr deletion a these deletion are thought to be a result of palindromic unit and nonhomologous recombination these microdeletions might impact in the interpretation of some clinical finding the rest of the case were assigned to category a normal variant polymorphismno deletion conclusion the present finding show that this new kit offer good sensitivity and specificity with the advantage of saving in term of cost and time
label: Non-Cancer

title: fiftyfour novel mutation in the nf gene and integrated analysis of the mutation that modulate splicing
abstract: neurofibromatosis type nf is a common autosomal dominant genetic disorder caused by mutation in the nf gene one of the hallmark of nf is the high mutation rate in this gene in this study we present different nf mutation and novel mutation detected at both the genomic dna and mrna level using a retrospective case series review we found that of these different mutation induced aberrant splicing of note of these splicing error were caused by exonic variant in addition one mutation produced mosaicism in the posttranscriptional profile however study investigating these splicing aberration are limited in order to better understand the pathogenicity of nf and to provide a more accurate interpretation in molecular diagnostic testing combined computational analysis were employed to elucidate the underlying mechanism of the variant modulating nf gene splicing
label: Non-Cancer

title: highquality dna from fingernail for genetic analysis
abstract: the availability of highquality germline dna is an important prerequisite for a variety of genetic analysis we have shown previously that fingernail clipping provide an optimal source of autologous constitutional dna for pcrbased application however most existing protocol for nucleic acid purification from nail do not provide sufficiently high yield of pure and intact dna for more demanding downstream analysis such a next generation sequencing ng we have extensively tested and systematically modified a number of different protocol for dna purification from nail material to optimize the yield and quality the integrity of dna wa determined by pcr amplification of short bp and longrange kb sequence using different target gene among the method tested the prepfiler forensic dna extraction kit wa identified a the most appropriate approach to isolation of highquality dna from nail clipping a standardized input of mg nail material to piece of fingernail clipping yielded a mean of mug dna range to mug subsequent pcranalysis revealed efficient amplifiability of short and midrange target in and and longrange fragment in of the sample tested the adequacy for next generation sequencing application wa demonstrated by successful highresolution hlatyping in ten transplant recipient hence the protocol presented facilitates the exploitation of fingernail material even for demanding genomic analysis both in research and diagnostics
label: Non-Cancer

title: peptideindependent stabilization of mhc class i molecule breach cellular quality control
abstract: the intracellular trafficking of major histocompatibility complex class i mhci protein is directed by three quality control mechanism that test for their structural integrity which is correlated to the binding of highaffinity antigenic peptide ligand to investigate which molecular feature of mhci these quality control mechanism detect we have followed the hypothesis that suboptimally loaded mhci molecule are characterized by their conformational mobility in the fpocket region of the peptidebinding site we have created a novel variant of an mhci protein kbyc in which two alphahelices in this region are linked by a disulfide bond that mimic the conformational and dynamic effect of bound highaffinity peptide kbyc show a remarkable increase in the binding affinity to it light chain beta microglobulin betam and bypass all three cellular quality control step our data demonstrate that coupling between peptide and betam binding to the mhci heavy chain is mediated by conformational dynamic that the folded conformation of mhci supported by betam play a decisive role in passing the ertocellsurface transport quality control and that betam association is also tested by the cell surface quality control that lead to mhci endocytosis
label: Non-Cancer

title: novel mechanism of transcriptional repression of the human atp binding cassette transporter a gene in hepatic cell by the winged helixforkhead box transcription factor a
abstract: atp binding cassette transporter a abca play a key role in the biogenesis of hdl by promoting the efflux of cellular cholesterol and phospholipid to lipid free apoai mutation in the abca gene cause tangier disease which is characterized by near or complete absence of circulating plasma hdl in the present study we show that the winged helixforkhead box containing transcription factor a foxa shown previously to play a role in glucose and bile acid homeostasis in the liver and in energy utilization in adipose tissue is a negative modulator of abca gene expression in hepatic cell we show that the abca promoter contains three foxa binding element in the proximal region two of the site are localized in a region of the abca promoter enriched in binding element for transcriptional repressor protein whereas the third site is the core of the tata element of the abca promoter inhibition of foxa binding to the abca promoter by sitedirected mutagenesis or foxa gene expression by sirna wa associated with increased abca promoter activity and protein level overexpression of foxa inhibited both the constitutive abca gene expression a well a abca gene induction by oxysterols and retinoids via nuclear receptor lxralpharxralpha in summary the present study identifies transcription factor foxa a a negative modulator of abca gene expression in hepatic cell and reveals a novel mechanism of transcriptional repression by foxa which involves the tata element of the abca gene
label: Non-Cancer

title: application of coldpcr for improved detection of nf mosaic mutation
abstract: somatic mosaicism represents the coexistence of two or more cell population with different genotype in one person and it is involved in monogenic disorder somatic mosaicism characterizes approximately to of patient with de novo neurofibromatosis type nf the identification of mosaicism is crucial to patient and their family because the clinical course of the disease and it transmission risk is influenced by the degree and distribution of mutated cell moreover in nf the capability of discriminating patient with mosaicism is especially important to make differential diagnosis with schwannomatosis however the identification of mosaic variant is considerably difficult and the development of specific molecular technique to detect low level of unknown molecular alteration is required coamplification at lower denaturation temperature coldpcr ha been described a a powerful method to selectively amplify minority allele from mixture of wildtype and mutationcontaining sequence here we applied coldpcr to molecular analysis of patient with nf mosaicism with the use of coldpcr followed by direct sequencing we were able to detect nf mutation in blood dna of three patient with nf mosaicism our study ha shown the capability of coldpcr in enriching lowrepresented mutated allele in blood dna sample making it usable for molecular diagnosis of patient with mosaicism
label: Non-Cancer

title: surgical treatment of lumbosacral pseudarthrosis and spondyloptosis in a patient with neurofibromatosis type and a large lumbar anterior meningocele case report and review of the literature
abstract: background lumbar anterior meningocele mc is rare in patient with neurofibromatosis type nf although spinal fusion with maximum possible resection of the cele might be indicated in these special case report describing operative procedure are lacking clinical presentation we present a young woman with nf and lower back pain due to lumbar anterior mc extensive osteolysis and deformation of the lumbar spine after harrington spondylodesis from t to s in she developed lumbosacral pseudarthrosis and transcutaneous migration of the spondylodesis thus the left pole of the spondylodesis wa shortened below the level of l in year later the patient presented with lower back pain and wound infection imaging revealed the mc and avulsion of the right s screw with lumbosacral pseudarthrosis and spondyloptosis and transcutaneous migration of the right spondylodesis pole threestage surgery wa indicated with explantation of the harrington system in the first step and posterior fusion from t to s in the second step finally vertebral resection gathering of the cele and implantation of a customized titanium cage wa achieved through an anterior transabdominal approach postoperatively the patient reported sufficient reduction of lower back pain conclusion lumbar anterior mc is rare in patient with nf and may cause spinal instability when surgery is indicated longrange spinal fusion and reduction of the cele should be considered surgery may be challenging requiring a staged operative procedure and an interdisciplinary collaboration
label: Non-Cancer

title: reducing falsepositive incidental finding with ensemble genotyping and logistic regression based variant filtering method
abstract: a whole genome sequencing wgs uncovers variant associated with rare and common disease an immediate challenge is to minimize falsepositive finding due to sequencing and variant calling error false positive can be reduced by combining result from orthogonal sequencing method but costly here we present variant filtering approach using logistic regression lr and ensemble genotyping to minimize false positive without sacrificing sensitivity we evaluated the method using paired wgs datasets of an extended family prepared using two sequencing platform and a validated set of variant in na using lr or ensemble genotyping based filtering falsenegative rate were significantly reduced by to fold at the same level of false discovery rate for heterozygous and for homozygous single nucleotide variant snvs for heterozygous and for homozygous insertion for heterozygous and for homozygous deletion compared to the filtering based on genotype quality score moreover ensemble genotyping excluded of of false positive while retaining of of true positive in de novo mutation dnm discovery in na and performed better than a consensus method using two sequencing platform our proposed method were effective in prioritizing phenotypeassociated variant and an ensemble genotyping would be essential to minimize falsepositive dnm candidate
label: Non-Cancer

title: chromatin and transcription transition of mammalian adult germline stem cell and spermatogenesis
abstract: adult germline stem cell agscs selfrenew thy enriched or commit to gametogenesis kit enriched to better understand how chromatin regulates agsc biology and gametogenesis we derived stagespecific highresolution profile of dna methylation hmc histone modificationsvariants and rnaseq in agscs and during spermatogenesis first we define striking signaling and transcriptional difference between agsc type involving key selfrenewal and proliferation pathway second key pluripotency factor eg nanog are silent in agscs and bear particular chromatindname attribute that may poise them for reactivation after fertilization third agscs display chromatin poisingbivalency of enhancer and promoter for embryonic transcription factor remarkably gametogenesis occurs without significant change in dname and instead involves transcription of dnamethylated promoter bearing high rnapol hkac hkme low cg content and often hmc furthermore key finding were confirmed in human sperm here we reveal agsc signaling asymmetry and chromatindname strategy in agscs to poise key transcription factor and to activate dnamethylated promoter during gametogenesis

title: a limited form of proteus syndrome with bilateral plantar cerebriform collagenomas and varicose vein secondary to a mosaic akt mutation
abstract: importance proteus syndrome is an extremely rare disorder of mosaic postnatal overgrowth affecting multiple tissue including bone soft tissue and skin it typically manifest in early childhood with asymmetric and progressive skeletal overgrowth that lead to severe distortion of the skeleton and disability the genetic basis ha recently been identified a a somatic activating mutation in the akt gene which encodes an enzyme mediating cell proliferation and apoptosis observation we present a yearold man who developed plantar cerebriform collagenomas on the sol of both foot and varicose vein in early childhood in the absence of any skeletal or other connective tissue abnormality although the patient did not meet the diagnostic criterion for proteus syndrome he wa found to have the cga pglulys akt mutation in lesional skin but not in his blood conclusion and relevance to our knowledge this is the mildest molecularly confirmed case of proteus syndrome occurring in the absence of the characteristic skeletal overgrowth these finding extend the spectrum of proteus syndrome pathological characteristic and suggest that somatic mutation late in development and restricted in distribution cause subtle clinical presentation that do not meet the published clinical criterion
label: Non-Cancer

title: tracking histone variant nucleosomes across the human cell cycle using biophysical biochemical and cytological analysis
abstract: histone variant such a h macroha haz and cenpa are important epigenetic modifier of the chromatin state in eukaryotic genome the centromeric histone h variant cenpacenh epigenetically mark centromere and is required for assembly of the kinetochore complex a region of the chromosome that is responsible for proper genome segregation during mitosis several diverse technique using biochemical cell biology and biophysical approach have been utilized to study the nature of the cenpa nucleosome across the cell cycle in this chapter we describe method for cenpa nucleosome purification and separation of cenpa from other core histone using traditional sdspage and more resolving technique such a triton acid urea tau and twodimensional gel we also discus method for observation of cenpa on chromatin fiber using immunofluorescence finally we provide a detailed description of analysis of chromatin structure using atomic force microscopy
label: Non-Cancer

title: a case of lateonset segmental neurofibromatosis
abstract: segmental neurofibromatosis nf is a rare variant of neurofibromatosis to our knowledge there have been few report of case presenting later in life the recognition of nf is important a there have been report of paraneoplastic manifestation and transmission to offspring here we present the case of a patient who presented with nf first appearing in her mids this case illustrates the subtle nature of nf which often lead to misdiagnosis
label: Non-Cancer

title: anaphylaxis a a clinical manifestation of clonal mast cell disorder
abstract: clonal mast cell disorder comprise a heterogeneous group of disorder characterized by the presence of gain of function kit mutation and a constitutively altered activationassociated mast cell immunophenotype frequently associated with clinical manifestation related to the release of mast cell mediator these disorder do not always fulfil the world health organization whoproposed criterion for mastocytosis particularly when lowsensitive diagnostic approach are performed anaphylaxis is a frequent presentation of clonal mast cell disorder particularly in mastocytosis patient without typical skin lesion the presence of cardiovascular symptom eg hypotension occurring after a hymenoptera sting or spontaneously in the absence of cutaneous manifestation such a urticaria is characteristic and differs from the presentation of anaphylaxis in the general population without mastocytosis
label: Non-Cancer

title: accuracy of pedicle screw placement in the thoracic and lumbosacral spine using a conventional intraoperative fluoroscopyguided technique a national neurosurgical education and training center analysis of consecutive screw
abstract: objective pedicle screw placement is a very common procedure used to stabilize all three column of the thoracic and lumbar spine the purpose of this study is to evaluate the incidence of screw misplacement and related complication in patient who underwent fluoroscopyguided transpedicular screw fixation at a neurosurgical teaching institution method we retrospectively reviewed consecutive patient who underwent fluoroscopyguided transpedicular screw fixation from january to may in the department of neurosurgery kantonsspital aarau a certified swiss national neurosurgical education and training center the accuracy of the pedicle screw trajectory wa assessed using reconstructed postoperative axial sagittal and coronal computed tomography image the displacement wa classified a minor mm result a total of pedicle screw were placed in consecutive patient in the thoracic and lumbosacral spine all surgery were performed under the supervision of boardcertified neurosurgeon and faculty member a total of surgeon including trainee participated in all procedure a total of screw breaching the pedicle were identified with minor violation moderate violation and severe violation sixteen patient developed postoperative radiculopathy all of these patient belonged to the subgroup of severe screw displacement conclusion the data presented confirm that for a training and education center transpedicular fluoroscopyguided screw fixation remains a technically demanding procedure a defined in this study neurological symptom are likely associated only with severe screw misplacement
label: Non-Cancer

title: evaluation and optimisation of indel detection workflow for ion torrent sequencing of the brca and brca gene
abstract: background the ion torrent pgm is a popular benchtop sequencer that show promise in replacing conventional sanger sequencing a the gold standard for mutation detection despite the pgms reported high accuracy in calling single nucleotide variation it tends to generate many false positive call in detecting insertion and deletion indels which may hinder it utility for clinical genetic testing result recently the proprietary analytical workflow for the ion torrent sequencer torrent suite t underwent a series of upgrade we evaluated three major upgrade of t by calling indels in the brca and brca gene our analysis revealed that false negative indels could be generated by t under both default calling parameter and parameter adjusted for maximum sensitivity however indel calling with the same data using the open source variant caller gatk and samtools showed that false negative could be minimised with the use of appropriate bioinformatics analysis furthermore we identified two variant calling measure qualitybydepth qd and variation of the width of gap and insert varw which substantially reduced false positive indels including nonhomopolymer associated error without compromising sensitivity in our best case scenario that involved the tmap aligner and samtools we achieved sensitivity specificity and false discovery rate fdr in indel calling from all sample which is a good performance for mutation screening using pgm conclusion new version of t bwa and gatk have shown improvement in indel calling sensitivity and specificity over their older counterpart however the variant caller of t exhibit a lower sensitivity than gatk and samtools our finding demonstrate that although indel calling from pgm sequence may appear to be noisy at first glance proper computational indel calling analysis is able to maximize both the sensitivity and specificity at the single base level paving the way for the usage of this technology for future clinical genetic testing
label: Non-Cancer

title: mpdrc prospective study of reducedintensity allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation in patient with myelofibrosis
abstract: from to patient with primary myelofibrosis or myelofibrosis mf preceded by essential thrombocythemia or polycythemia vera were enrolled into a prospective phase clinical trial of reducedintensity allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation ahsct myeloproliferative disorder research consortium trial the study included patient with sibling donor n receiving fludarabinemelphalan flumel a a preparative regimen and patient with unrelated donor n receiving conditioning with flumel plus antithymocyte globulin atg patient characteristic in the cohort were similar engraftment occurred in of sibling and of unrelated transplant whereas secondary graft failure occurred in and respectively with a median followup of month for patient alive the overall survival o wa in the sibling group median not reached and in the unrelated group median o month confidence interval ci hazard ratio ci p nonrelapse mortality wa in sibling and in unrelated ahsct survival correlated with type of donor but not with the degree of histocompatibility match age or jakvf status in patient with mf with sibling donor ahsct is an effective therapy whereas ahsct from unrelated donor with flumelatg conditioning led to a high rate of graft failure and limited survival this trial wa registered at wwwclinicaltrialsgov a nct
label: Non-Cancer

title: gene expression profile in longterm non progressor hiv infected patient in search of potential resistance factor
abstract: longterm nonprogressors ltnp represent a minority of hivinfected individual characterized by documented infection for more than year a stable cd t cell count over mm and low viremia in the absence of antiretroviral treatment protective factor described so far such a the ccrdelta deletion protective hla allele or defective virus fail to fully explain the partial protection phenotype the existence of additional host resistance mechanism in ltnp patient wa investigated here using a whole human genome microarray study comparing gene expression profile of unstimulated peripheral blood mononuclear cell from ltnp patient hiv infected patient under antiretroviral therapy with cd t cell level above mm st a well a healthy individual gene that were up or downregulated exclusively in ltnp st or in both group in comparison to control were identified and classified in functional category using ingenuity pathway analysis st and ltnp patient group revealed distinct genetic profile regarding gene number in each category and up or downregulation of specific gene which could have a bearing on the outcome of each group we selected some relevant gene to validate the differential expression using quantitative realtime qrtpcr among others we found several gene related to the canonical wntbetacatenin signaling pathway our result identify new possible host gene and molecule that could be involved in the mechanism leading to the slower progression to aid and sustained cd t cell count that is peculiar to ltnp patient
label: Non-Cancer

title: ataxia telangiectasia derived ip cell show preserved xray sensitivity and decreased chromosomal instability
abstract: ataxia telangiectasia is a neurodegenerative inherited disease with chromosomal instability and hypersensitivity to ionizing radiation ip cell lacking atm atips cell exhibited hypersensitivity to xray irradiation one of the characteristic of the disease while parental ataxia telangiectasia cell exhibited significant chromosomal abnormality atips cell did not show any chromosomal instability in vitro for at least passage day whole exome analysis also showed a comparable nucleotide substitution rate in atips cell taken together these data show that atm is involved in protection from irradiationinduced cell death
label: Non-Cancer

title: a novel mutation in the csfr gene cause a variable leukoencephalopathy with spheroid
abstract: hereditary diffuse leukoencephalopathy with neuroaxonal spheroid is a neurodegenerative disease associated with mutation in the colonystimulating factor receptor gene csfr a yearold woman with a year history of depression presented with neurological sign and a recent cognitive decline the diagnosis of hereditary diffuse leukoencephalopathy with neuroaxonal spheroid wa suspected based on the finding of a predominant frontal leukoencephalopathy and neuroaxonal spheroid on brain biopsy she share with her mother a novel csfr exon missense mutation cg a pvm the mother ha a longstanding bipolar disorder and mild multifocal white matter abnormality in her s this is the first report of hereditary diffuse leukoencephalopathy with neuroaxonal spheroid due to this novel csfr missense mutation our report suggests that either marked intrafamilial variability or incomplete penetrance can be associated with csfr mutation the observation of a small bone cyst in our patient support the hypothesis that hereditary diffuse leukoencephalopathy with neuroaxonal spheroid and polycystic lipomembranous osteodysplasia with sclerosing leukoencephalopathy may belong to a spectrum of overlapping phenotype
label: Non-Cancer

title: dermatologic and dental aspect of the international tuberous sclerosis complex consensus statement
abstract: importance the international tuberous sclerosis complex clinical consensus conference wa convened to update the last consensus statement in skin and dental lesion are common in tuberous sclerosis complex tsc and are a frequent concern for patient recognition of these lesion is imperative for early diagnosis given the treatment advance that may improve patient outcome objective to detail recommendation for the diagnosis surveillance and management of skin and dental lesion in tsc evidence review the tsc dermatology and dentistry subcommittee of subcommittee reviewed the relevant literature from to finding a consensus on skin and dental issue wa achieved within the dermatology and dentistry subcommittee before recommendation were presented discussed and agreed on in a group meeting of all subcommittee from june to conclusion and relevance skin and dental finding comprise of major feature and of minor feature in the diagnostic criterion a definite diagnosis of tsc is defined a the presence of at least major feature or major and or more minor feature in addition a pathological mutation in tsc or tsc is diagnostic skin and oral examination should be performed annually and every to month respectively intervention may be indicated for tsc skin or oral lesion that are bleeding symptomatic disfiguring or negatively affecting function option presented include surgical excision laser or use of a mammalian target of rapamycin inhibitor
label: Non-Cancer

title: the presence of mast cell clonality in patient with unexplained anaphylaxis
abstract: background the mechanism by which mast cell in patient with unexplained anaphylaxis uea are triggered remain elusive onset of episode is unpredictable and often recurrent the substantial overlap between the clinical manifestation of uea and clonal mast cell disorder cmd suggests an association between these rare disorder the two form of cmd characterized to date are systemic mastocytosis sm and monoclonal mast cell activation syndrome mmas objective to examine the hypothesis that the pathogenesis of uea reflects the presence of aberrant subpopulation of mast cell method thirty men woman patient year suffering from uea and with no sign of cutaneous mastocytosis were recruited patient underwent an initial complete allergy workup to confirm the diagnosis of uea level of baseline serum tryptase sbt and total ige were determined in addition a bone marrow examination wa performed on all patient to investigate possible underlying cmd result fourteen of our case nine men five woman were diagnosed with cmd with sm and four with mmas four of the patient with sm had mast cell aggregate in their bone marrow all patient with sm exhibited a sbt level ngml whereas this level wa elevated in only two of those with mmas and four with uae but not diagnosed with cmd total ige level were lower in the group of patient with cmd p ngml and cardiovascular symptom such a syncope
label: Non-Cancer

title: the role of serum erythropoietin level and jak vf allele burden in the diagnosis of polycythaemia vera
abstract: low serum erythropoietin epo is a minor criterion of polycythaemia vera pv but it diagnostic usefulness relies on study performed before the discovery of jak vf mutation the objective of the present study wa to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of serum epo and jak vf allele burden a marker of pv a well a the combination of different diagnostic criterion in patient with pv with essential thrombocythaemia and with nonclonal erythrocytosis low epo showed good diagnostic accuracy a a marker for pv with the area under the curve auc of the chemiluminescentenhanced enzyme immunoassay ceia being better than that of radioimmunoassay ria and for ceia and ria respectively jak vf quantification displayed an excellent diagnostic accuracy with an auc of a haematocrit male or female plus the presence of the jak vf mutation had a sensitivity and specificity of and respectively adding low epo or the jak vf allele burden did not improve the diagnostic accuracy for pv whereas the inclusion of both improved the sensitivity up to and maintaining specificity haematocrit and qualitative jak vf mutation allow a reliable diagnosis of pv incorporation of epo andor jak vf mutant load doe not improve the diagnostic accuracy
label: Non-Cancer

title: ataxia telangiectasia more variation at clinical and cellular level
abstract: ataxia telangiectasia at is a rare recessively inherited disorder resulting in a progressive neurological decline it is caused by biallelic mutation of the atm gene that encodes a kda serinethreonine protein kinase responsible for phosphorylating many target protein atm is activated by autotransphosphorylation in response to dna double strand break and lead to the activation of cell cycle checkpoint and either dna repair or apoptosis a part of the cellular response to dna damage the allelic heterogeneity in at is striking while the majority of mutation are truncating leading to instability and loss of the atm protein from the allele a significant proportion of patient carry one of a small number of mutation that are either missense or leaky splice site mutation resulting in retention of some atm with activity the allelic heterogeneity in atm therefore result in an equally striking clinical heterogeneity there is also locus heterogeneity because mutation of the mre gene can cause an obvious at like disorder both clinically and also at the cellular level and mutation of the rnf gene result in a much milder clinical phenotype neurologically with the major clinical feature being an immunological defect
label: Non-Cancer

title: prenatal diagnosis of clove syndrome confirmed by detection of a mosaic pikca mutation in cultured amniocytes
abstract: congenital lipomatous asymmetric overgrowth of the trunk lymphatic capillary venous and combinedtype vascular malformation epidermal nevus skeletal and spinal anomaly clove syndrome a segmental overgrowth syndrome is caused by post zygotic somatic mutation in pikca a gene involved in the receptor tyrosine kinase phosphatidylinositol kinase piakt growthsignaling pathway prenatal ultrasound finding of lymphovascular malformation segmental overgrowth and skeletal defect can raise suspicion for clove syndrome but molecular confirmation of pikca mutation on prenatally obtained sample is challenging because of somatic mosaicism we detected a mosaic diseasecausing mutation in pikca by sequencing of dna extracted from cultured amniotic cell but not from dna directly prepared from an amniotic fluid sample in a fetus with prenatally suspected clove syndrome the infant wa born prematurely and displayed severe lymphovascular malformation and segmental overgrowth consistent with a clinical diagnosis of clove syndrome he passed away at day of life we discus the complexity and limitation of genetic testing for somatic mosaic mutation in the prenatal period and highlight the potential need for multiple approach to arrive at a molecular diagnosis wiley periodical inc
label: Non-Cancer

title: selective suppression of excessive glunc expression rescue early epilepsy in a tuberous sclerosis murine model
abstract: tuberous sclerosis complex tsc caused by dominant mutation in either tsc or tsc tumour suppressor gene is characterized by the presence of brain malformation the cortical tuber that are thought to contribute to the generation of pharmacoresistant epilepsy here we report that tuberless heterozygote tsc mouse show functional upregulation of cortical glunccontaining nmethyldaspartate receptor nmdars in an mtordependent manner and exhibit recurrent unprovoked seizure during early postnatal life p seizure are generated intracortically in the granular layer of the neocortex slow kinetics of aberrant gluncmediated current in spiny stellate cell promotes excessive temporal integration of persistent nmdarmediated recurrent excitation and seizure generation accordingly specific gluncd antagonist block seizure in tsc mouse in vivo and in vitro likewise glunc expression is upregulated in tsc human surgical resection and a gluncd antagonist reduces paroxysmal hyperexcitability thus glunc receptor constitutes a promising molecular target to treat epilepsy in tsc patient
label: Non-Cancer
combined_text: selective suppression of excessive glunc expression rescue early epilepsy in a tuberous sclerosis murine model tuberous sclerosis complex tsc caused by dominant mutation in either tsc or tsc tumour suppressor gene is characterized by the presence of brain malformation the cortical tuber that are thought to contribute to the generation of pharmacoresistant epilepsy here we report that tuberless heterozygote tsc mouse show functional upregulation of cortical glunccontaining nmethyldaspartate receptor nmdars in an mtordependent manner and exhibit recurrent unprovoked seizure during early postnatal life p seizure are generated intracortically in the granular layer of the neocortex slow kinetics of aberrant gluncmediated current in spiny stellate cell promotes excessive temporal integration of persistent nmdarmediated recurrent excitation and seizure generation accordingly specific gluncd antagonist block seizure in tsc mouse in vivo and in vitro likewise glunc expression is upregulated in tsc human surgical resection and a gluncd antagonist reduces paroxysmal hyperexcitability thus glunc receptor constitutes a promising molecular target to treat epilepsy in tsc patient

title: participation of the eligase trim in nfkappab p activation and nfatdependent activation of crel upon tcell receptor engagement
abstract: the nuclear factor kappab nfkappab family member p and crel chiefly orchestrate lymphocyte activation following tcell receptor tcr engagement in contrast to p which is rapidly mobilized crel activation occurs subsequently a it involves a nuclear factor of activated tcells nfatdependent upregulation step however how tcr ligation drive p and crel activation is not fully understood because several ubiquitylated component of nfkappab signaling cascade accumulate in close proximity to membrane we screened a sirna library against eligases that contain transmembrane domain on tcrmediated nfkappab activation here we report the identification of the endoplasmic reticulum resident trim protein a an enhancer of nfkappab promoter activity we found that knocking down trim by rna interference reduced the activation of p while the translocation of crel into the nucleus wa blunted we further observed that crel induction wa diminished without trim a nfat activation wa compromised these result unveil that trim is a selective regulator of p and of crel activation
label: Non-Cancer

title: overexpression of gremlin in patient with loeysdietz syndrome implication on pathophysiology and early disease detection
abstract: background the loeysdietz syndrome lds is an inherited connective tissue disorder caused by mutation in the transforming growth factor beta tgfbeta receptor tgfbr or tgfbr most patient with lds develop severe aortic aneurysm resulting in early need of surgical intervention in order to gain further insight into the pathophysiology of the disorder we investigated circulating outgrowth endothelial cell oec from the peripheral blood of lds patient from a cohort of patient including patient with novel tgfbeta receptor mutation method and result we performed gene expression profiling of oecs using microarray analysis followed by quantitative pcr for verification of gene expression compared to oecs of age and sexmatched healthy control oecs isolated from three lds patient displayed altered expression of several gene belonging to the tgfbeta pathway especially those affecting bone morphogenic protein bmp signalling including bmp bmp and bmpra gene expression of bmp antagonist gremlin grem showed the most prominent upregulation this increase wa confirmed at the protein level by immunoblotting of ldsoecs in immunohistochemistry abundant gremlin protein expression could be verified in endothelial cell a well a smooth muscle cell within the arterial medium furthermore gremlin plasma level of lds patient were significantly elevated compared to healthy control subject conclusion these finding open new avenue in the understanding of the pathogenesis of loeysdietz syndrome and the development of new diagnostic serological method for early disease detection
label: Non-Cancer

title: poor performance of the determine hiv agab combo fourthgeneration rapid test for detection of acute infection in a national household survey in swaziland
abstract: fourthgeneration hiv rapid test rts claim to detect both p antigen ag and hiv antibody ab for early identification of acute infection important for targeting prevention and reducing hiv transmission in a nationally representative household survey in swaziland adult age to year received homebased hiv rapid testing in and of the individual were ab positive ab by the determine hiv abab combo test and of those were confirmed to be reactive in the unigold test determine combo identified individual a having acute infection agab negative ab however none had detectable hiv rna and of remained hiv negative at their week followup visit were lost to followup all rtnonreactive sample were pooled and tested by nucleic acid amplification testing naat to identify acute infection naat identified of the hiv antibodynegative specimen a hiv rna positive with rna level ranging from to copiesml however none of them were ag by determine combo followup testing of of the naatpositive individual at month demonstrated seroconversions individual wa lost to followup therefore the determine combo test had a sensitivity of confidence interval to and positive predictive value of for the detection of acute infection the ability of the thgeneration determine combo to detect antigen wa very poor in swaziland thus the determine combo test doe not add any value to the current testing algorithm rather it add additional cost and complexity to hiv diagnosis the detection of acute hiv infection may need to rely on other testing strategy
label: Non-Cancer

title: metabolism and insulin signaling in common metabolic disorder and inherited insulin resistance
abstract: type diabetes obesity and polycystic ovary syndrome pcos are common metabolic disorder which are observed with increasing prevalence and which are caused by a complex interplay between genetic and environmental factor including increased calorie intake and physical inactivity these metabolic disorder are all characterized by reduced plasma adiponectin and insulin resistance in peripheral tissue quantitatively skeletal muscle is the major site of insulin resistance both low plasma adiponectin and insulin resistance contribute to an increased risk of type diabetes and cardiovascular disease in several study we have investigated insulin action on glucose and lipid metabolism and at the molecular level insulin signaling to glucose transport and glycogen synthesis in skeletal muscle from healthy individual and in obesity pcos and type diabetes moreover we have described a novel syndrome characterized by postprandial hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia and insulin resistance this syndrome is caused by a mutation in the tyrosine kinase domain of the insulin receptor gene insr we have studied individual with this mutation a a model of inherited insulin resistance type diabetes obesity and pcos are characterized by pronounced defect in the insulinstimulated glucose uptake in particular glycogen synthesis and to a lesser extent glucose oxidation and the ability of insulin to suppress lipid oxidation in inherited insulin resistance however only insulin action on glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis is impaired this suggests that the defect in glucose and lipid oxidation in the common metabolic disorder are secondary to other factor in young woman with pcos the degree of insulin resistance wa similar to that seen in middleaged patient with type diabetes this support the hypothesis of an unique pathogenesis of insulin resistance in pcos insulin in physiological concentration stimulates glucose uptake in human skeletal muscle in vivo by activation of the insulin signaling cascade to glucose transport through the enzyme irs pik akt astbcd and rac and to glycogen synthesis through akt inhibition of gsk and activation of glycogen synthase g via dephosphorylation of serine residue in both the nhterminal site a and the coohterminal end site ab in type diabetes obesity and pcos there is although with some variation from study to study defect in insulin signaling through irs pik akt and astbcd which can explain reduced insulin action on glucose transport in type diabetes an altered intracellular distribution of snap and impaired activation of rac also seem to play a role for reduced insulin action on glucose transport in all common metabolic disorder we observed an impaired insulin activation of g which seems to be caused by attenuated dephosphorylation of g at site a whereas a the inhibition of gsk and the dephosphorylation of g at it target site site aa appeared to be completely normal in individual with inherited insulin resistance we observed largely the same defect in insulin action on irs pik akt and g a well a a normal inhibition of gsk and dephosphorylation of g at site ab in these individual however a markedly reduced insulin clearance seems to partially rescue insulin signaling to glucose transport and g adiponectin is thought to improve insulin sensitivity primarily by increasing lipid oxidation through activation of the enzyme ampk and possibly via crosstalking of adiponectin with insulin signaling and hence glucose transport and glycogen synthesis we demonstrated a strong correlation between plasma adiponectin and insulin action on glucose disposal and glycogen synthesis in obesity type diabetes and pcos in individual with inherited insulin resistance plasma adiponectin wa normal but the correlation of adiponectin with insulinstimulated glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis wa at least equally strong moreover we found a correlation between plasma adiponectin and insulin activation of g this result is supported by a number of recent study of animal model and muscle cell line which have shown that adiponectin augments insulin action on enzyme in the insulin signaling cascade in contrast we observed no difference in the abundance or activity of ampk in obesity type diabetes pcos or inherited insulin resistance this indicates that reduced insulin sensitivity in these condition is not mediated via abnormal ampk activity the result from these study demonstrate that the wellestablished abnormality in insulin action on glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis are reflected by defect in insulin signaling to these cellular process in type diabetes obesity and pcos and a expected also in inherited insulin resistance caused by a mutation in insr in common metabolic disorder low plasma adiponectin may contribute to insulin resistance and defect in insulin signaling whereas in inherited insulin resistance a normal plasma adiponectin and reduced insulin clearance could contribute to maintain a sufficient activation of the insulin signaling cascade the insight gained from these study have improved our understanding of the molecular mechanism underlying insulin resistance in skeletal muscle of human and can form the basis for further study which can lead to the development of treatment that more directly target insulin resistance and hence reduce the risk of type diabetes and cardiovascular disease
label: Non-Cancer

however only insulin action on glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis is impaired this suggests that the defect in glucose and lipid oxidation in the common metabolic disorder are secondary to other factor in young woman with pcos the degree of insulin resistance wa similar to that seen in middleaged patient with type diabetes this support the hypothesis of an unique pathogenesis of insulin resistance in pcos insulin in physiological concentration stimulates glucose uptake in human skeletal muscle in vivo by activation of the insulin signaling cascade to glucose transport through the enzyme irs pik akt astbcd and rac and to glycogen synthesis through akt inhibition of gsk and activation of glycogen synthase g via dephosphorylation of serine residue in both the nhterminal site a and the coohterminal end site ab in type diabetes obesity and pcos there is although with some variation from study to study defect in insulin signaling through irs pik akt and astbcd which can explain reduced insulin action on glucose transport in type diabetes an altered intracellular distribution of snap and impaired activation of rac also seem to play a role for reduced insulin action on glucose transport in all common metabolic disorder we observed an impaired insulin activation of g which seems to be caused by attenuated dephosphorylation of g at site a whereas a the inhibition of gsk and the dephosphorylation of g at it target site site aa appeared to be completely normal in individual with inherited insulin resistance we observed largely the same defect in insulin action on irs pik akt and g a well a a normal inhibition of gsk and dephosphorylation of g at site ab in these individual however a markedly reduced insulin clearance seems to partially rescue insulin signaling to glucose transport and g adiponectin is thought to improve insulin sensitivity primarily by increasing lipid oxidation through activation of the enzyme ampk and possibly via crosstalking of adiponectin with insulin signaling and hence glucose transport and glycogen synthesis we demonstrated a strong correlation between plasma adiponectin and insulin action on glucose disposal and glycogen synthesis in obesity type diabetes and pcos in individual with inherited insulin resistance plasma adiponectin wa normal but the correlation of adiponectin with insulinstimulated glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis wa at least equally strong moreover we found a correlation between plasma adiponectin and insulin activation of g this result is supported by a number of recent study of animal model and muscle cell line which have shown that adiponectin augments insulin action on enzyme in the insulin signaling cascade in contrast we observed no difference in the abundance or activity of ampk in obesity type diabetes pcos or inherited insulin resistance this indicates that reduced insulin sensitivity in these condition is not mediated via abnormal ampk activity the result from these study demonstrate that the wellestablished abnormality in insulin action on glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis are reflected by defect in insulin signaling to these cellular process in type diabetes obesity and pcos and a expected also in inherited insulin resistance caused by a mutation in insr in common metabolic disorder low plasma adiponectin may contribute to insulin resistance and defect in insulin signaling whereas in inherited insulin resistance a normal plasma adiponectin and reduced insulin clearance could contribute to maintain a sufficient activation of the insulin signaling cascade the insight gained from these study have improved our understanding of the molecular mechanism underlying insulin resistance in skeletal muscle of human and can form the basis for further study which can lead to the development of treatment that more directly target insulin resistance and hence reduce the risk of type diabetes and cardiovascular disease

title: early neurodevelopmental screening in tuberous sclerosis complex a potential window of opportunity
abstract: background infant born with tuberous sclerosis complex a genetic condition resulting from a mutation in tsc or tsc are at increased risk for intellectual disability andor autism feature of epilepsy neuropathology genetics a well a timing and type of mechanismbased medication have been proposed a risk factor neurodevelopmental outcome have been reported among these study however few include data about the individual early neurodevelopmental profile a factor that may contribute significantly to these outcome further there is no clinical standard for the neurodevelopmental assessment of these infant the paucity of data regarding the natural history of neurodevelopment in infant with tuberous sclerosis complex and the lack of a gold standard for neurodevelopmental evaluation present a significant challenge for clinician and researcher method during the first year of life we tracked the onset of infantile spasm the type and timing of antiepileptic treatment and the associated response of two agematched infant with tuberous sclerosis complex we also employed capute scale a a part of a structured neurodevelopmental evaluation to characterize and compare their neurodevelopmental profile result infant developed infantile spasm with confirmed hypsarrhythmia at month of age treatment with vigabatrin wa initiated within hour with near immediate cessation of seizure and no further seizure to date expressive language delay wa detected at month and treated with speech andor language therapy infant developed complex partial seizure at month treatment included levetiracetam oxcarbazepine and the ketogenic diet vigabatrin wa initiated on detection of hypsarrhythmia after month intractable epilepsy persists to date global developmental delay wa evident by month and treated with physical occupational and speech andor language therapy conclusion many risk factor have been associated with intellectual disability andor autism in individual with tuberous sclerosis complex however few data are available regarding practical clinical tool for early identification in our case series inclusion of the capute scale a a part of routine medical care led to the identification of developmental delay in the first month of life and selection of targeted neurodevelopmental intervention development of a riskbased assessment using this approach will be the focus of future study a it may provide a potential window of opportunity for both research and clinical purpose in research it may serve a an objective outcome measure clinically this type of assessment ha potential for informing clinical treatment decision and serving a a prognostic indicator of longterm cognitive and psychiatric outcome

title: prognostic value of postoperative urinary retention after male sling insertion
abstract: introduction while urinary retention is a known complication of advance male sling am placement for postprostatectomy incontinence ppi there is minimal data regarding ultimate continence outcome for patient who experience this complication the purpose of this study wa to determine the rate of continence after am placement in patient who had postoperative urinary retention a compared with those patient who did not material and method a retrospective review wa conducted of patient who underwent am placement for ppi between and with postoperative void trial tov preoperative factor such a urodynamic finding daily pad number ppd and weight were recorded follow up data included pad use need for catheterization and complication statistical analysis compared patient with and without postoperative urinary retention result thirtyfive patient were included with a mean follow up of month complete continence wa while of patient were improved ppd improved from pad to pad after am placement sixteen patient had postoperative urinary retention requiring clean intermittent catheterization cic of the patient in postoperative retention were completely continent ppd compared to of patient who passed first tov p all patient who required cic were able to void within day conclusion postoperative urinary retention after am placement for ppi occurs in about of patient and is shortlived patient who experienced postoperative urinary retention had good continence outcome
label: Non-Cancer

title: iljanus kinasesignal transducer and activator of transcription signaling dysregulates bim expression in autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome
abstract: background autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome alp is a human disorder of t cell homeostasis caused by mutation that impair fasmediated apoptosis a defining characteristic of alp is the expansion of double negative t cell dntc relatively little is known about how defective fasdriven cell death and the bcl apoptotic pathway intersect in alp patient objective we studied change in bcl family member expression in alp to determine whether the bcl pathway might provide a therapeutic target method we used flow cytometry to analyze the expression of pro and antiapoptotic bcl family member in t cell from alp patient and determined the in vitro sensitivity of alp dntc to the proapoptotic bh mimetic abt result the proapoptotic molecule bim wa significantly elevated in dntc although no general pattern of individual antiapoptotic bcl family member emerged increased expression of bim wa always accompanied by increased expression of at least antiapoptotic bcl family member strikingly bim level in dntc correlated significantly with serum il in alp patient and il wa sufficient to mildly induce bim in normal and alp t cell via a janus kinasesignal transducer and activator of transcription dependent mechanism finally abt preferentially killed alp dntc in vitro conclusion combined these data show that an iljanus kinasesignal transducer and activator of transcription pathway drive bim expression in alp dntc which render them sensitive to bh mimetics uncovering a potentially novel therapeutic approach to alp
label: Non-Cancer

title: bimodal activation of bubr by bub sustains mitotic checkpoint signaling
abstract: the mitotic checkpoint also known a the spindle assembly checkpoint prevents premature anaphase onset through generation of an inhibitor of the e ubiquitin ligase apcc whose ubiquitination of cyclin b and securin target them for degradation combining in vitro reconstitution and cellbased assay we now identify dual mechanism through which bub promotes mitotic checkpoint signaling bub enhances signaling at unattached kinetochore not only by facilitating binding of bubr but also by enhancing cdc recruitment to kinetochore mediated by bubrs internal cdc binding site downstream of kinetochoreproduced complex bub promotes binding of bubrs conserved amino terminal cdc binding domain to a site in cdc that becomes exposed by initial mad binding this latter bubstimulated event generates the final mitotic checkpoint complex of bubbubrcdc that selectively inhibits ubiquitination of securin and cyclin b by apcccdc thus bub promotes two distinct bubrcdc interaction involving each of the two cdc binding site of bubr and acting at unattached kinetochore or cytoplasmically respectively to facilitate production of the mitotic checkpoint inhibitor
label: Non-Cancer

title: mastl is required for timely activation of apcc in meiosis i and cdk reactivation in meiosis ii
abstract: in mitosis the greatwall kinase called microtubuleassociated serinethreonine kinase like mastl in mammal is essential for prometaphase entry or progression by suppressing protein phosphatase a ppa activity ppa suppression in turn lead to high level of cdk substrate phosphorylation we have used a mouse model with an oocytespecific deletion of mastl to show that mastlnull oocyte resume meiosis i and reach metaphase i normally but that the onset and completion of anaphase i are delayed moreover after the completion of meiosis i mastlnull oocyte failed to enter meiosis ii mii because they reassembled a nuclear structure containing decondensed chromatin our result show that mastl is required for the timely activation of anaphasepromoting complexcyclosome to allow meiosis i exit and for the rapid rise of cdk activity that is needed for the entry into mii in mouse oocyte
label: Non-Cancer

title: defining the role of common variation in the genomic and biological architecture of adult human height
abstract: using genomewide data from individual we identified variant at genomewide significance that together explained onefifth of the heritability for adult height by testing different number of variant in independent study we show that the most strongly associated and snp explained and of phenotypic variance furthermore all common variant together captured of heritability the variant clustered in locus were enriched for gene pathway and tissue type known to be involved in growth and together implicated gene and pathway not highlighted in earlier effort such a signaling by fibroblast growth factor wntbetacatenin and chondroitin sulfaterelated gene we identified several gene and pathway not previously connected with human skeletal growth including mtor osteoglycin and binding of hyaluronic acid our result indicate a genetic architecture for human height that is characterized by a very large but finite number thousand of causal variant
label: Non-Cancer

title: langerhans cell histiocytosis
abstract: background langerhans cell histiocytosis lch is a rare histiocytic disorder of unknown etiopathogenesis it clinical presentation is variable and range from isolated skin or bone disease to a lifethreatening multisystem condition lch can occur at any age but is more frequent in the pediatric population a neoplastic origin of this disease ha been suggested due to the discovery of the mutually exclusive activating somatic braf ve and mapk gene mutation that occur in about of patient method a survey of recent literature focused on the diagnosis management and prognosis of langerhans cell histiocytosis data were collected analyzed and discussed with an emphasis on contemporary clinical practice result lch is common in the pediatric population compared with adult child usually have a more aggressive clinical course that requires systemic chemotherapy patient with lowrisk lch have an excellent prognosis and a longterm survival rate that may be a high a by contrast patient with highrisk lch have a survival rate close to typically adult patient present with limited skin or bone involvement that can be treated with surgical resection or focal radiation therapy resulting in an overall survival rate of smoking cessation can result in the improvement of respiratory symptom and the spontaneous resolution of pulmonary lch targeted therapy with braf inhibitor ha been used in select patient with lch and the result have been encouraging conclusion our understanding of lch ha improved in the last year available treatment regimen can control the disease in the majority of patient the discovery of novel driver mutation and the development of targeted therapy promise better outcome with fewer longterm therapyrelated adverse event particularly for pediatric and adolescent patient
label: Non-Cancer

title: gene therapy for inherited muscle disease where genetics meet rehabilitation medicine
abstract: the development of clinical vector to correct genetic mutation that cause inherited myopathy and related disorder of skeletal muscle is advancing at an impressive rate adenoassociated virus vector are attractive for clinical use because adenoassociated virus do not cause human disease and these vector are able to persist for year new vector are now becoming available a gene therapy delivery tool and recent preclinical experiment have demonstrated the feasibility safety and efficacy of gene therapy with adenoassociated virus for longterm correction of muscle pathology and weakness in myotubularindeficient canine and murine disease model in this review recent advance in the application of gene therapy to treat inherited muscle disorder are presented including duchenne muscular dystrophy and xlinked myotubular myopathy potential area for therapeutic synergy between rehabilitation medicine and genetics are also discussed
label: Non-Cancer
combined_text: gene therapy for inherited muscle disease where genetics meet rehabilitation medicine the development of clinical vector to correct genetic mutation that cause inherited myopathy and related disorder of skeletal muscle is advancing at an impressive rate adenoassociated virus vector are attractive for clinical use because adenoassociated virus do not cause human disease and these vector are able to persist for year new vector are now becoming available a gene therapy delivery tool and recent preclinical experiment have demonstrated the feasibility safety and efficacy of gene therapy with adenoassociated virus for longterm correction of muscle pathology and weakness in myotubularindeficient canine and murine disease model in this review recent advance in the application of gene therapy to treat inherited muscle disorder are presented including duchenne muscular dystrophy and xlinked myotubular myopathy potential area for therapeutic synergy between rehabilitation medicine and genetics are also discussed

title: prospective blinded study of brafve mutation detection in cellfree dna of patient with systemic histiocytic disorder
abstract: unlabelled patient with langerhans cell histiocytosis lch and erdheimchester disease ecd have a high frequency of brafve mutation and respond to raf inhibitor however detection of mutation in tissue biopsy is particularly challenging in histiocytoses due to low tumor content and stromal contamination we applied a dropletdigital pcr assay for quantitative detection of the brafve mutation in plasma and urine cellfree cf dna and performed a prospective blinded study in patient with ecdlch there wa concordance between tissue and urinary cfdna genotype in treatmentnaive sample cfdna analysis facilitated identification of previously undescribed krasgsmutant ecd and dynamically tracked disease burden in patient treated with a variety of therapy these result indicate that cfdna brafve mutational analysis in plasma and urine provides a convenient and reliable method of detecting mutational status and can serve a a noninvasive biomarker to monitor response to therapy in lch and ecd significance patient with brafvemutant histiocytic disorder have remarkable response to raf inhibition but mutation detection in tissue in these disorder is challenging here we identify that analysis of plasma and urinary cfdna provides a reliable method to detect the brafve mutation and monitor response to therapy in these disorder
label: Non-Cancer

title: microscopic validation of macroscopic in vivo image enabled by sameslide optical and nuclear fusion
abstract: unlabelled it is currently difficult to determine the molecular and cellular basis for radioscintigraphic signal obtained during macroscopic in vivo imaging the field is in need of technology that help bridge the macroscopic and microscopic regime to solve this problem we developed a fiducial marker fm simultaneously compatible with color nearinfrared nir fluorescence and nm autoradiography and conventional hematoxylineosin he histology method the fm wa constructed from an optimized concentration of commercially available human serum albumin and nm nir fluorophores mtcpertechnetate dimethyl sulfoxide and glutaraldehyde lymphangioleiomyomatosis cell coexpressing the sodium iodide symporter and green fluorescent protein were labeled with nm fluorophore and mtcpertechnatate and then administered intratracheally into cd mouse after in vivo spect imaging and ex vivo spect and nir fluorescence imaging of the lung mum frozen section were prepared and processed for nm nir fluorophore costaining autoradiography and he staining on the same slide using the fm to coregister all datasets result optimized fm composed of mum unlabeled human serum albumin mum nir fluorescent human serum albumin dimethyl sulfoxide and glutaraldehyde in phosphatebuffered saline ph were prepared within min displayed homogeneity and stability and were visible by all imaging modality including he staining using these fm tissue displaying high signal by spect could be dissected and analyzed on the same slide and at the microscopic level for nm nir fluorescence nm nir fluorescence autoradiography and he histopathologic staining conclusion when multimodal fm are combined with a new technique for simultaneous sameslide nir fluorescence imaging autoradiography and he staining macroscopic in vivo image can now be studied unambiguously at the microscopic level
label: Non-Cancer
