title: romiplostim in child with immune thrombocytopenia a phase randomised doubleblind placebocontrolled study
abstract: background the thrombopoietin receptor agonist romiplostim could be an effective treatment in symptomatic child with persistent or chronic immune thrombocytopenia we aimed to assess whether romiplostim is safe and effective in child with immune thrombocytopenia of more than month duration method in this phase doubleblind study eligible participant were child with immune thrombocytopenia aged year to year and mean platelet count x l or less mean of two measurement during the screening period with no single count greater than x l and were recruited from site in the usa canada and australia participant were randomly assigned through the interactive voice response system to receive weekly romiplostim or placebo for week stratified by age year to x l without rescue drug use in the preceding week in or more of the final week week this study is registered with clinicaltrialsgov nct finding between jan and sept patient were randomly assigned to romiplostim and to placebo durable platelet response wa seen in patient in the romiplostim group and two in the placebo group p odds ratio ci durable platelet response rate with romiplostim by age were for year to younger than year for year to younger than year and for year to younger than year one of patient in the placebo group had serious adverse event compared with of patient in the romiplostim group of these serious adverse event headache and thrombocytosis in one of patient in the romiplostim group were considered treatment related no patient withdrew due to adverse event interpretation in child with chronic immune thrombocytopenia romiplostim induced a high rate of platelet response with no new safety signal ongoing romiplostim study will provide further information a to longterm efficacy safety and remission in child with immune thrombocytopenia funding amgen inc

title: thrombopoietin receptor agonist use in child data from the pediatric itp consortium of north america icon study
abstract: background data on secondline treatment option for pediatric patient with immune thrombocytopenia itp are limited thrombopoietin receptor agonist tpora provide a nonimmunosuppressive option for child who require an increased platelet count procedure we performed a multicenter retrospective study of pediatric itp patient followed at itp consortium of north america icon site to characterize tpora use result seventynine child had a total of treatment eltrombopag romiplostim and eight trialed on both the majority had primary itp and most had chronic itp however had persistent itp and had newly diagnosed itp during the first month of treatment achieved a platelet count x l romiplostim eltrombopag p at least once in the absence of rescue therapy the average time to a response wa week for romiplostim and week for eltrombopag p only of patient demonstrated a stable response with consistent dosing over time an intermittent response with constant dose titration wa seen in and an initial response that waned to no response wa seen in significant adverse event were minimal with the exception of two patient with thrombotic event and one who developed a neutralizing antibody conclusion our result demonstrate that tpora agent are being used in child with itp of varying duration and severity the response wa similar to clinical trial but the sustainability of response varied future study need to focus on the ideal timing and rationale for these medication in pediatric patient
label: Non-Cancer

title: telomereassociated aging disorder
abstract: telomere are dynamic nucleoproteindna structure that cap and protect linear chromosome end several monogenic inherited disease that display feature of human premature aging correlate with shortened telomere and are referred to collectively a telomeropathies these disorder have overlapping symptom and a common underlying mechanism of telomere dysfunction but also exhibit variable symptom and age of onset suggesting they fall along a spectrum of disorder primary telomeropathies are caused by defect in the telomere maintenance machinery whereas secondary telomeropathies have some overlapping symptom with primary telomeropathies but are generally caused by mutation in dna repair protein that contribute to telomere preservation here we review both the primary and secondary telomeropathies discus potential mechanism for tissue specificity and age of onset and highlight outstanding question in the field and future direction toward elucidating disease etiology and developing therapeutic strategy
label: Non-Cancer

title: everolimus improves neuropsychiatric symptom in a patient with tuberous sclerosis carrying a novel tsc mutation
abstract: tuberous sclerosis complex tsc is a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by multiple symptom including neuropsychological deficit such a seizure intellectual disability and autism tsc is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern and is caused by mutation in either the tsc or tsc gene which enhance activation of the mammalian target of rapamycin mtor signaling pathway recent study have suggested that mtor inhibitor such a rapamycin can reverse tscassociated deficit in rodent model of tsc in addition clinical trial are ongoing to test the efficacy of mtor inhibitor toward the psychiatric symptom associated with tsc here we report a case study of a korean patient with tsc who exhibited multiple symptom including frequent seizure intellectual disability language delay and social problem we performed whole exome sequencing and identified a novel small deletion mutation in tsc expressing the novel deletion mutant in hekt cell significantly increased mtor pathway activation furthermore everolimus treatment showed not only reduction in sega size but dramatically improved behavioral deficit including autism related behavior in the patient in summary we identified a novel small deletion mutation in tsc associated with severe tsc in a korean family that enhances the activation of mtor signaling in vitro everolimus treatment improved behavioral deficit in the patient
label: Non-Cancer

title: angiopoietin mediates thrombininduced monocyte adhesion and endothelial permeability
abstract: unlabelled essential mechanism of thrombininduced inflammation is not fully understood thrombin induced monocyte adhesion and barrier loss require angiopoietin ang ang mediates vessel leakage and monocyte adhesion through shppmapk pathway calcium dependent shppmapk activation regulates ang expression through a feedback loop summary background thrombin imparts an inflammatory phenotype to the endothelium by promoting increased monocyte adhesion and vascular permeability however the molecular player that govern these event are incompletely understood objective the aim of this study wa to determine whether angiopoietin ang ha a role if any in regulating inflammatory signal initiated by thrombin method assessment of vascular leakage by mile assay wa performed by intradermal injection on the foot paw surface level of intercellular adhesion molecule icam were determined by flow cytometry overexpression knockdown and phosphorylation of protein were determined by western blotting result in timecourse experiment thrombinstimulated ang upregulation peaked prior to the expression of adhesion molecule icam in human umbilical veinderived endothelial cell huvecs knockdown of ang blocked both thrombininduced monocyte adhesion and icam expression in addition ang mouse displayed defective vascular leakage when treated with thrombin introducing ang protein in ang mouse failed to recover a wildtype phenotype mechanistically ang appears to regulate the thrombinactivated calcium spike that is required for tyrosine phosphatase shp and p mapk activation further downregulation of shp attenuated both thrombininduced ang expression and monocyte adhesion downregulation of the adaptor protein gab a coactivator of shp a well a overexpression of the gab mutant incapable of interacting with shp yfgab inhibited thrombinmediated effect including downstream activation of p mapk which in turn wa required for ang expression conclusion the data establish an essential role of the gabshppmapk signaling pathway and ang in regulating thrombininduced monocyte adhesion and vascular leakage

adhesion and vascular leakage

title: mutsbeta promotes trinucleotide repeat expansion by recruiting dna polymerase beta to nascent cagn or ctgn hairpin for errorprone dna synthesis
abstract: expansion of cag ctg repeat cause a number of familial neurodegenerative disorder although the underlying mechanism remains largely unknown component involved in dna mismatch repair particularly mismatch recognition protein mutsbeta a mshmsh heterodimer are implicated in cag ctg repeat expansion in addition to recognizing small insertiondeletion loopouts mutsbeta also specifically bind dna hairpin imperfect heteroduplexes formed within cagn ctgn sequence however whether or not and how mutsbeta binding trigger expansion of cag ctg repeat remain unknown we show here that purified recombinant mutsbeta physically interacts with dna polymerase beta polbeta and stimulates polbetacatalyzed cagn or ctgn hairpin retention consistent with these in vitro observation mutsbeta and polbeta interact with each other in vivo and colocalize at cag ctg repeat during dna replication our data support a model for errorprone processing of cagn or ctgn hairpin by mutsbeta and polbeta during dna replication andor repair mutsbeta recognizes cagn or ctgn hairpin formed in the nascent dna strand and recruit polbeta to the complex which then utilizes the hairpin a a primer for extension leading to cag ctg repeat expansion this study provides a novel mechanism for trinucleotide repeat expansion in both dividing and nondividing cell
label: Non-Cancer
combined_text: mutsbeta promotes trinucleotide repeat expansion by recruiting dna polymerase beta to nascent cagn or ctgn hairpin for errorprone dna synthesis expansion of cag ctg repeat cause a number of familial neurodegenerative disorder although the underlying mechanism remains largely unknown component involved in dna mismatch repair particularly mismatch recognition protein mutsbeta a mshmsh heterodimer are implicated in cag ctg repeat expansion in addition to recognizing small insertiondeletion loopouts mutsbeta also specifically bind dna hairpin imperfect heteroduplexes formed within cagn ctgn sequence however whether or not and how mutsbeta binding trigger expansion of cag ctg repeat remain unknown we show here that purified recombinant mutsbeta physically interacts with dna polymerase beta polbeta and stimulates polbetacatalyzed cagn or ctgn hairpin retention consistent with these in vitro observation mutsbeta and polbeta interact with each other in vivo and colocalize at cag ctg repeat during dna replication our data support a model for errorprone processing of cagn or ctgn hairpin by mutsbeta and polbeta during dna replication andor repair mutsbeta recognizes cagn or ctgn hairpin formed in the nascent dna strand and recruit polbeta to the complex which then utilizes the hairpin a a primer for extension leading to cag ctg repeat expansion this study provides a novel mechanism for trinucleotide repeat expansion in both dividing and nondividing cell

title: ctnnb mutation and estrogen receptor expression in neuromuscular choristoma and it associated fibromatosis
abstract: neuromuscular choristoma nmc is a very rare developmental malformation characterized by the endoneurial intercalation of mature muscle fiber among peripheral nerve fiber nmc typically arises in the major proximal peripheral nerve most commonly the sciatic nerve and may involve the lumbosacral and brachial plexus patient present clinically with progressive neuropathy or plexopathy nmc is strongly associated with development of a fibromatosis histologically identical to conventional desmoidtype fibromatosis nmcfibromatosis the development of nmcfibromatosis is often precipitated by iatrogenic trauma ie biopsy desmoidtype fibromatosis is characterized by ctnnb exon mutation which result in aberrant nuclear betacatenin localization and dysregulated canonical wnt signaling in contrast the pathogenesis of nmc and nmcfibromatosis is unknown desmoidtype fibromatosis express estrogen receptor er specifically the erbeta isoform erbeta and endocrine therapy may be used in surgically unresectable case in contrast the er expression profile of nmcfibromatosis is unknown we evaluated a series of nmc and nmcfibromatosis for ctnnb mutation betacatenin expression and er isoform expression five nmcs occurred in female and male patient median age y range t psf and c ag pta four patient subsequently developed nmcfibromatosis and all case contained ctnnb mutation including pta and psf mutation in patient the nmc and nmcfibromatosis had identical ctnnb mutation only nmc had no detectable ctnnb mutation however the patient subsequent nmcfibromatosis had a ctnnb pta mutation all nmc and nmcfibromatosis showed aberrant nuclear localization of betacatenin nuclear erbeta expression and no eralpha expression the presence of ctnnb mutation both in nmc and nmcfibromatosis may be a shared molecular genetic abnormality underlying their pathogenesis
label: Non-Cancer

title: crebbp mutation in individual without rubinsteintaybi syndrome phenotype
abstract: mutation in crebbp cause rubinsteintaybi syndrome by using exome sequencing and by using sanger in one patient crebbp mutation were detected in patient who did not or only in a very limited manner resemble rubinsteintaybi syndrome the combined facial sign typical for rubinsteintaybi syndrome were absent none had broad thumb and three had only somewhat broad hallux all had apparent developmental delay being the reason for molecular analysis five had short stature and seven had microcephaly the facial characteristic were variable main characteristic were short palpebral fissure telecanthi depressed nasal ridge short nose anteverted naris short columella and long philtrum six patient had autistic behavior and two had selfinjurious behavior other symptom were recurrent upper airway infection n feeding problem n and impaired hearing n major malformation occurred infrequently all patient had a de novo missense mutation in the last part of exon or beginning of exon of crebbp between base pair and codon and no missense or truncating mutation in this region have been described to be associated with the classical rubinsteintaybi syndrome phenotype no functional study have yet been performed but we hypothesize that the mutation disturb proteinprotein interaction by altering zinc finger function we conclude that patient with missense mutation in this specific crebbp region show a phenotype that differs substantially from that in patient with rubinsteintaybi syndrome and may prove to constitute one or more separate entity wiley periodical inc
label: Non-Cancer

title: the cilium a cellular antenna with an influence on obesity risk
abstract: primary cilium are organelle that are present on many different cell type either transiently or permanently they play a crucial role in receiving signal from the environment and passing these signal to other part of the cell in that way they are involved in diverse process such a adipocyte differentiation and olfactory sensation mutation in gene coding for ciliary protein often have pleiotropic effect and lead to clinical condition ciliopathies with multiple symptom in this study we reviewed observation from ciliopathies with obesity a one of the symptom it show that variation in ciliarelated gene is itself not a major cause of obesity in the population but may be a part of the multifactorial aetiology of this complex condition both common polymorphism and rare deleterious variant may contribute to the obesity risk genotypephenotype relationship have been noticed among the ciliary gene obesity differs with regard to severity and age of onset which may relate to the influence of each gene on the balance between pro and antiadipogenic process analysis of the function and location of the protein encoded by these ciliary gene suggests that obesity is more linked to activity at the basal area of the cilium including initiation of the intraflagellar transport but less to the intraflagellar transport itself regarding the role of cilium three possible mechanistic process underlying obesity are described adipogenesis neuronal food intake regulation and food odour perception
label: Non-Cancer

title: largescale exomewide association analysis identifies locus for white blood cell trait and pleiotropy with immunemediated disease
abstract: white blood cell play diverse role in innate and adaptive immunity genetic association analysis of phenotypic variation in circulating white blood cell wbc count from large sample of otherwise healthy individual can provide insight into gene and biologic pathway involved in production differentiation or clearance of particular wbc lineage myeloid lymphoid and also potentially inform the genetic basis of autoimmune allergic and blood disease we performed an exome arraybased metaanalysis of total wbc and subtype count neutrophil monocyte lymphocyte basophil and eosinophil in a multiancestry discovery and replication sample of individual from study we identified common variant of which were coding variant associated with one or more wbc trait the majority of which are pleiotropically associated with autoimmune disease based on functional annotation these locus included gene encoding surface marker of myeloid lymphoid or hematopoietic stem cell differentiation cd cd cd transcription factor regulating lineage specification during hematopoiesis asxl irf ikzf jmjdc etspsmg and molecule involved in neutrophil clearanceapoptosis corf lta adhesion tnxb or centrosome and microtubule structurefunction kif tubd together with recent report of somatic asxl mutation among individual with idiopathic cytopenia or clonal hematopoiesis of undetermined significance the identification of a common regulatory utr variant of asxl suggests that both germline and somatic asxl mutation contribute to lower blood count in otherwise asymptomatic individual these association result shed light on genetic mechanism that regulate circulating wbc count and suggest a prominent shared genetic architecture with inflammatory and autoimmune disease
label: Non-Cancer

title: usefulness of fetal autopsy in the diagnosis of blomstrand chondrodysplasia a report of three case
abstract: blomstrand osteochondrodysplasia bocd is a rare autosomal recessive sclerosing skeletal dysplasia characterized by accelerated chondrocyte differentiation in this article we discus three case where lethal skeletal dysplasia wa suspected and blomstrand dysplasia wa diagnosed by autopsy antenatal ultrasound finding include increased nuchal translucency tetramicromelia and polyhydramnios radiological hallmark is advanced skeletal maturation and bone sclerosis histology of long bone revealed narrow cartilagenous cap and change in the physeal growth zone which showed severe hypoplasia and disorganization of proliferative phase and hypertrophic phase homozygous and compound heterozygous mutation in pthr gene have been implicated in the pathogenesis of this chondrodysplasia
label: Non-Cancer

title: the er membraneanchored ubiquitin ligase hrd is a positive regulator of tcell immunity
abstract: identification of positive regulator of tcell immunity induced during autoimmune disease is critical for developing novel therapy the endoplasmic reticulum resident ubiquitin ligase hrd ha recently emerged a a critical regulator of dendritic cell antigen presentation but it role in tcell immunity is unknown here we show that genetic deletion of hrd in mouse inhibits tcell proliferation production of il and differentiation of th and th cell and consequently protects mouse from experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis hrd facilitates tcell proliferation by the destruction of cyclindependent kinase inhibitor pkip and deletion of pkip in hrdnull tcells rescue proliferative capacity but not the production of cytokine including il ifngamma and il tcell expression of hrd is higher in patient with multiple sclerosis than in healthy individual and knockdown of hrd in human cd t cell inhibits activation and differentiation to th and th cell our study identifies hrd a a previously unappreciated positive regulator of t cell and implies that hrd is a potential therapeutic target for autoimmune disease
label: Non-Cancer

title: the impact of mosaicism in preimplantation genetic diagnosis pgd approach to pgd for dominant disorder in couple without family history
abstract: objective mosaicism in certain dominant disorder may result in a nonmendelian transmission for the causative mutation preimplantation genetic diagnosis pgd is available for patient with inherited disorder to achieve an unaffected pregnancy we present our experience for two female patient with different dominantly inherited autosomal disorder neurofibromatosis type nf and tuberous sclerosis complex type tsc method pgd protocol development wa carried out using single cell from the patient pgd wa carried out on polar body and different embryonic cell result protocol development for nf using lymphocyte from the patient suggested mosaicism for the mutation this wa supported further by quantitative fluorescentpcr performed on genomic dna during pgd polar body and blastomere lacked the mutation that probably wa absent or present at very low level in the patient germline single lymphocyte analysis during protocol development for tsc did not indicate mosaicism however analysis of single buccal cell and multiple embryo biopsy across two consecutive ivfpgd cycle confirmed gonosomal mosaicism conclusion the trend in pgd is for blastocyst biopsy followed by whole genome amplification eliminating single cell analysis in the case of certain dominantly inherited disorder prepgd single cell analysis is beneficial to identify potential mosaicism that ensures robust protocol john wiley son ltd
label: Non-Cancer

title: erdheimchester disease with novel gene mutation discovered a an incidental finding in explanted liver of a patient with hepatitis c cirrhosis a case report and literature review
abstract: erdheimchester disease ecd is a rare form of nonlangerhans cell histiocytosis characterized by xanthogranulomatous infiltration of foamy histiocyte frequently involving bone and other organ system we herein report a unique case of ecd discovered incidentally in an explanted liver in a yearold male with endstage liver disease secondary to hepatitis c cirrhosis histological examination and immunohistochemical study in the explanted liver revealed prominent foamy histiocyte that were cd positive but cda and s negative mutational hotspot analysis of the explanted liver using a panel of most common cancerrelated gene performed by next generation sequencing ng revealed likely somatic mutation in the pdgfra pten and hnfa gene but no braf codon mutation were detected the bone marrow showed similar finding a in the liver whole body pet and bone scan demonstrated increased heterogeneous uptake in bilateral humeral and femoral diaphysis most compatible with ecd to our knowledge this is the first case report of ecd that involves mainly bone marrow and liver with novel genomic alteration our case highlight the diversity and complexity of this disease entity and the importance of multimodality approach integrating clinical and radiologic feature with histopathologic and moleculargenomic finding
label: Non-Cancer
combined_text: erdheimchester disease with novel gene mutation discovered a an incidental finding in explanted liver of a patient with hepatitis c cirrhosis a case report and literature review erdheimchester disease ecd is a rare form of nonlangerhans cell histiocytosis characterized by xanthogranulomatous infiltration of foamy histiocyte frequently involving bone and other organ system we herein report a unique case of ecd discovered incidentally in an explanted liver in a yearold male with endstage liver disease secondary to hepatitis c cirrhosis histological examination and immunohistochemical study in the explanted liver revealed prominent foamy histiocyte that were cd positive but cda and s negative mutational hotspot analysis of the explanted liver using a panel of most common cancerrelated gene performed by next generation sequencing ng revealed likely somatic mutation in the pdgfra pten and hnfa gene but no braf codon mutation were detected the bone marrow showed similar finding a in the liver whole body pet and bone scan demonstrated increased heterogeneous uptake in bilateral humeral and femoral diaphysis most compatible with ecd to our knowledge this is the first case report of ecd that involves mainly bone marrow and liver with novel genomic alteration our case highlight the diversity and complexity of this disease entity and the importance of multimodality approach integrating clinical and radiologic feature with histopathologic and moleculargenomic finding

title: tuberous sclerosis complex associated with vascular anomaly or overgrowth
abstract: background dysregulation of the mammalian target of rapamycin pathway is the underlying pathogenic mechanism in tuberous sclerosis complex tsc other syndrome caused by genetic alteration in this pathway frequently manifest a vascular anomaly or asymmetric overgrowth rarely these feature have been documented in tsc objective to collate case of tsc with vascular anomaly or overgrowth that have been published and to assemble additional recent case a this finding ha been underreported method tsc case from three pediatric dermatology referral center on two continent were reviewed to identify individual noted to have hemihypertrophy or vascular anomaly result we report five additional case of tsc associated with vascular anomaly or overgrowth that contribute to our understanding of some of the pathway and treatment involved in vascular anomaly conclusion hemihypertrophy and vascular anomaly may be more frequent in the setting of tsc than previously appreciated a common pathogenetic mechanism may tie these manifestation together
label: Non-Cancer

title: erdheimchester disease with emperipolesis a unique case involving the heart
abstract: histiocytosis is an uncommon disease characterized by excessive accumulation of histiocyte here we report a rare case of nonlangerhanscell histiocytosis in a yearold woman who presented with severe symptom of pericardial effusion radiologic investigation also detected multiple bone lower limb vertebra rib and ilium lesion resected pericardium showed abundant mono or multinucleated nonfoamy histiocyte cdcdscdalphalangerin in a fibroinflammatory background the histiocyte demonstrated emperipolesis of lymphocyte a hallmark feature of rosaidorfman disease rdd however molecular analysis revealed a braf ve mutation of the proliferating histiocyte highlighting the neoplastic feature frequently observed in another nonlangerhanscell histiocytosis known a erdheimchester disease ecd we consider this case to be a unique presentation of ecd harboring some rddlike cell with emperipolesis but not a case of rdd with a braf mutation concerning it clinical manifestation involvement of the heart and bone and neoplastic feature
label: Non-Cancer

title: defining a new aggressiveness classification and using nfatc localization a a prognostic factor in cherubism
abstract: cherubism is a rare genetic disease characterized by bilateral giant cell reparative granuloma of the jaw consisting of a fibrotic stroma with giant multinucleated cell gmcs and osteoclastic feature cherubism severity is highly variable and recurrence after surgery is the most important risk currently there are no prognostic indicator the aim of this study were to evaluate the osteoclastogenesis phenotype by histologic examination of nuclear factor of activated t cell nfatc localization and tartrateresistant acid phosphatase trap activity and to correlate the result to disease aggressiveness to define prognostic indicator based on cherubism evolution year after surgery class of cherubism aggressiveness were identified mild group a moderate group b and severe group c histologically in grade a and b cherubism lesion gmcs were negative for both trap activity and nfatc nuclear localization in contrast in grade c cherubism lesion gmcs were all positive for trap activity and nfatc nuclear localization and displayed osteoclastlike feature other histopathologic finding were not different among the group our result establish that trap activity and nftac nuclear localization are associated with aggressive cherubism and therefore could be added to routine pathologic examination to aid in prognosis and management of the disease the finding of nfatc nuclear localization in aggressive tumor support the addition of anticalcineurin treatment to the therapeutic arsenal for cherubism
label: Non-Cancer

title: mastocytosis
abstract: mastocytosis is a rare disease caused by excessive production of mast cell clinical presentation is variable often based on the type of mastocytosis but in all type of mastocytosis there seems to be an increase in the risk of anaphylaxis systemic mastocytosis is diagnosed based on bone marrow biopsy treatment is variable based on the type of mastocytosis but trigger avoidance and anaphylaxis treatment are mainstay there are no therapy that change the natural course of mastocytosis for cutaneous mastocytosis treatment is conservative and aimed at symptom relief
label: Non-Cancer

title: molecular hydrogen suppresses activated wntbetacatenin signaling
abstract: molecular hydrogen h is effective for many disease however molecular base of h have not been fully elucidated cumulative evidence indicates that h act a a gaseous signal modulator we found that h suppresses activated wntbetacatenin signaling by promoting phosphorylation and degradation omicronf betacatenin either complete inhibition of gsk or mutation at ck and gskphosphorylation site of betacatenin abolished the suppressive effect of h h did not increase gskmediated phosphorylation of glycogen synthase indicating that h ha no direct effect on gsk itself knockdown of adenomatous polyposis coli apc or axin which form the betacatenin degradation complex minimized the suppressive effect of h on betacatenin accumulation accordingly the effect of h requires ckgskphosphorylation site of betacatenin a well a the betacatenin degradation complex comprised of ck gsk apc and axin we additionally found that h reduces the activation of wntbetacatenin signaling in human osteoarthritis chondrocytes oral intake of h water tended to ameliorate cartilage degradation in a surgeryinduced rat osteoarthritis model through attenuating betacatenin accumulation we first demonstrate that h suppresses abnormally activated wntbetacatenin signaling which account for the protective role of h in a fraction of disease
label: Non-Cancer

title: gene panel sequencing improves the diagnostic workup of patient with idiopathic erythrocytosis and identifies new mutation
abstract: erythrocytosis is a rare disorder characterized by increased red cell mass and elevated hemoglobin concentration and hematocrit several genetic variant have been identified a cause for erythrocytosis in gene belonging to different pathway including oxygen sensing erythropoiesis and oxygen transport however despite clinical investigation and screening for these mutation the cause of disease can not be found in a considerable number of patient who are classified a having idiopathic erythrocytosis in this study we developed a targeted nextgeneration sequencing panel encompassing the exonic region of gene from relevant pathway kb and sequenced patient with idiopathic erythrocytosis the panel effectively screened of coding region of these gene with an average coverage of x it identified different rare variant all leading to alteration of protein sequence with out of case having at least one of these variant ten of these were known erythrocytosiscausing variant which had been missed following existing diagnostic algorithm twentytwo were novel variant in erythrocytosisassociated gene egln epa vhl bpgm jak shb and in novel gene included in the panel eg epo egln hifa o some with a high likelihood of functionality for which future segregation functional and replication study will be useful to provide further evidence for causality the rest were classified a polymorphism overall these result demonstrate the benefit of using a gene panel rather than existing method in which focused genetic screening is performed depending on biochemical measurement the gene panel improves diagnostic accuracy and provides the opportunity for discovery of novel variant
label: Non-Cancer
combined_text: gene panel sequencing improves the diagnostic workup of patient with idiopathic erythrocytosis and identifies new mutation erythrocytosis is a rare disorder characterized by increased red cell mass and elevated hemoglobin concentration and hematocrit several genetic variant have been identified a cause for erythrocytosis in gene belonging to different pathway including oxygen sensing erythropoiesis and oxygen transport however despite clinical investigation and screening for these mutation the cause of disease can not be found in a considerable number of patient who are classified a having idiopathic erythrocytosis in this study we developed a targeted nextgeneration sequencing panel encompassing the exonic region of gene from relevant pathway kb and sequenced patient with idiopathic erythrocytosis the panel effectively screened of coding region of these gene with an average coverage of x it identified different rare variant all leading to alteration of protein sequence with out of case having at least one of these variant ten of these were known erythrocytosiscausing variant which had been missed following existing diagnostic algorithm twentytwo were novel variant in erythrocytosisassociated gene egln epa vhl bpgm jak shb and in novel gene included in the panel eg epo egln hifa o some with a high likelihood of functionality for which future segregation functional and replication study will be useful to provide further evidence for causality the rest were classified a polymorphism overall these result demonstrate the benefit of using a gene panel rather than existing method in which focused genetic screening is performed depending on biochemical measurement the gene panel improves diagnostic accuracy and provides the opportunity for discovery of novel variant

title: molecular screening strategy for nflike syndrome with cafeaulait macule review
abstract: multiple cafeaulait macule calm are usually associated with neurofibromatosis type nf one of the most common hereditary disorder however a group of genetic disorder presenting with calm have mutation that are involved in human skin pigmentation regulation signaling pathway including kit ligandkit protooncogene receptor tyrosine kinase and rasmitogenactivated protein kinase these disorder which include legius syndrome noonan syndrome with multiple lentigo or leopard syndrome and familial progressive hyperpigmentation are difficult to distinguish from nf at early stage using skin appearance alone furthermore certain syndrome are clinically overlapping and molecular testing is a vital diagnostic method the present review aim to provide an overview of these nflike inherited disease and recommend a costeffective strategy for making a clear diagnosis among these disease with an ambiguous borderline
label: Non-Cancer

title: proximal interphalangeal joint fibromatosis after pyrocarbon implant insertion a case report
abstract: background pyrocarbon implant represent an increasingly popular method to treat proximal interphalangeal joint dysfunction to this point no association ha been shown between pyrocarbon biomaterials and fibromatosis we present a potentially serious and destructive complication associated with pyrocarbon arthroplasty method we demonstrate a clinical case involving pyrocarbon arthroplasty and subsequent fibromatosis development in an otherwise healthy yearold female to present this association we illustrate the diagnostic workup involved in a rapidly expanding soft tissue mass of the hand and explain the appropriate treatment result pyrocarbon arthroplasty wa associated with development of locally destructive fibromatosis confirmed by histopathological examination treatment involved wide resection with preservation of local structure conclusion we describe the first association between fibromatosis and pyrocarbon biomaterial due to fibromatosis destructive effect clinician should be aware of potential complication associated with these material and know how to accurately diagnose and treat these lesion
label: Non-Cancer

title: dnamva vaccination of hiv infected participant with viral suppression on antiretroviral therapy followed by treatment interruption elicitation of immune response without control of reemergent virus
abstract: gvth a phase openlabel trial of a dna primemodified vaccinia ankara mva boost vaccine govxb wa undertaken in hiv infected participant on antiretroviral treatment art to evaluate safety and vaccineelicited t cell response and explore the ability of elicited cd t cell to control viral rebound during analytical treatment interruption ti nine men who began antiretroviral therapy art within month of seroconversion and had sustained plasma hiv rna copiesml for at least month were enrolled median age wa year median preart hiv rna wa copiesml and mean baseline cd count wa mul two dna followed by mva inoculation were given week apart eight subject completed all vaccination and ti clinical and laboratory adverse event were generally mild with no serious or grade event only reactogenicity event were considered related to study drug no treatment emergent viral resistance wa seen the vaccination did not reduce viral reservoir and virus reemerged in all participant during ti with a median time to reemergence of week eight of participant had cd t cell that could be stimulated by vaccinematched gag peptide prior to vaccination vaccination boosted these response a well a eliciting previously undetected cd response elicited t cell did not display sign of exhaustion during ti temporal pattern of viral reemergence and gagspecific cd t cell expansion suggested that vaccinespecific cd t cell had been stimulated by reemergent virus in only of participant in these transient decrease in viremia were associated with gag selection in known cd t cell epitope we hypothesize that escape mutation already archived in the viral reservoir plus a poor ability of cd t cell to traffic to and control virus at site of reemergence limited the therapeutic efficacy of the dnamva vaccine trial registration clinicaltrialsgov nct
label: Non-Cancer

title: the nlrp inflammasome function a a driver of the myelodysplastic syndrome phenotype
abstract: despite genetic heterogeneity myelodysplastic syndrome mdss share feature of cytological dysplasia and ineffective hematopoiesis we report that a hallmark of mdss is activation of the nlrp inflammasome which drive clonal expansion and pyroptotic cell death independent of genotype md hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell hspcs overexpress inflammasome protein and manifest activated nlrp complex that direct activation of caspase generation of interleukinbeta ilbeta and il and pyroptotic cell death mechanistically pyroptosis is triggered by the alarmin sa that is found in excess in md hspcs and bone marrow plasma further like somatic gene mutation sainduced signaling activates nadph oxidase nox increasing level of reactive oxygen specie ro that initiate cation influx cell swelling and betacatenin activation notably knockdown of nlrp or caspase neutralization of sa and pharmacologic inhibition of nlrp or nox suppress pyroptosis ro generation and nuclear betacatenin in mdss and are sufficient to restore effective hematopoiesis thus alarmins and founder gene mutation in mdss license a common redoxsensitive inflammasome circuit which suggests new avenue for therapeutic intervention
label: Non-Cancer

title: rathke cleft cyst with evidence of rupture into subarachnoid space
abstract: background a rathke cleft cyst rcc with nonhemorrhagic rupture mimicking pituitary apoplexy ha been reported rarely case description a yearold woman previously diagnosed with asymptomatic rcc came to u with a severe headache along with visual dysfunction and symptom of pituitary insufficiency fluidattenuated inversion recovery magnetic resonance imaging demonstrated diffuse hyperintensity in the cerebral cistern whereas watery clear cerebrospinal fluid wa obtained by lumbar puncture surgery performed month after onset revealed a nonhemorrhagic lesion with a final diagnosis of nonhemorrhagic rcc rupture conclusion we conclude that nonhemorrhagic rcc rupture and subsequent leakage of the content into subarachnoid space were the underlying pathogenesis in the present case of rcc resembling apoplexy
label: Non-Cancer

title: cutaneous and visceral chronic granulomatous disease triggered by a rubella virus vaccine strain in child with primary immunodeficiency
abstract: persistence of rubella live vaccine ha been associated with chronic skin granuloma in child with primary immunodeficiency we describe additional child with these finding including with visceral extension to the spleen
label: Non-Cancer
combined_text: cutaneous and visceral chronic granulomatous disease triggered by a rubella virus vaccine strain in child with primary immunodeficiency persistence of rubella live vaccine ha been associated with chronic skin granuloma in child with primary immunodeficiency we describe additional child with these finding including with visceral extension to the spleen

title: synchronization and desynchronization of cell by intervention on the spindle assembly checkpoint
abstract: cell cycle checkpoint are surveillance mechanism that sequentially and continuously monitor cell cycle progression thereby contributing to the preservation of genetic stability among them the spindle assembly checkpoint sac prevents the occurrence of abnormal division by halting the metaphase to anaphase transition following the detection of erroneous microtubuleskinetochore attachment most synchronization strategy are based on the activation of cell cycle checkpoint to enrich the population of cell in a specific phase of the cell cycle here we develop a twostep protocol of sequential cell synchronization and desynchronization employing antimitotic sacinducing agent ie nocodazole or paclitaxel in combination with the depletion of the sac kinase mp we describe cytofluorometric and timelapse videomicroscopy method to detect cell cycle progression including the assessment of cell cycle distribution quantification of mitotic cell fraction and analysis of single cell fate profile of living cell we applied these method to validate the synchronizationdesynchronization protocol and to qualitatively and quantitatively determine the impact of sac inactivation on the activity of antimitotic agent
label: Non-Cancer

title: case report of whole genome sequencing in the xy female identification of a novel sry mutation and revision of a misdiagnosis of androgen insensitivity syndrome
abstract: background the xy female is characterised by a male karyotype and female phenotype arising due to any interruption in the sexual development pathway in utero the cause is usually genetic and various gene are implicated case presentation herein we describe a xy woman who wa first diagnosed with androgen insensitivity syndrome testicular feminisation at year however this wa later questioned due to the presence of intact mullerian structure the clinical phenotype suggested several susceptibility gene including sry dhh nra nrb ar amh and amhr to study candidate gene simultaneously we performed whole genome sequencing this revealed a novel and likely pathogenic missense variant pargpro cgc in sry one of the major gene implicated in complete gonadal dysgenesis hence securing this condition over androgen insensitivity syndrome a the cause of the patient disorder of sexual development conclusion this case highlight the emerging clinical utility of whole genome sequencing a a tool in differentiating disorder of sexual development
label: Non-Cancer

title: a unique case of multiple nonossifying fibroma with polyostotic monomelic distribution and aggressive clinical course
abstract: multiple nonossifying fibroma mnofs occur either isolated or in association with other anomaly are usually localized in the long bone of the lower limb may be radiographically confused with other skeletal lesion and tend to heal spontaneously with the completion of the skeletal growth segmental distribution either monomelic or polymelic and ipsilateral is rare and commonly observed in the context of developmental disease known a rasopathies which are caused by mutation in gene that encode component or regulator within the rasmitogenactivated protein kinase signaling pathway we describe here the radiographic and pathologic feature of an yearold caucasian boy whose clinical history started at the age of when the diagnosis of aneurysmal bone cyst wa made on a lytic lesion of his left clavicle over the following year the patient developed polyostotic and monomelic lesion within the left humerus radius and ulna no other skeletal and extraskeletal anomaly were clinically detected the lesion were interpreted a consistent with polyostotic fibrous dysplasia and mnofs and showed an unusually aggressive clinical course with progressive increase in size and coalescence the definitive diagnosis of mnofs wa made after the exclusion of fibrous dysplasia by molecular analysis the polyostotic and monomelic distribution of the lesion and the unusually aggressive clinical course contribute to make this case of mnofs unique
label: Non-Cancer

title: primary autoimmune myelofibrosis a case report and review of the literature
abstract: autoimmune myelofibrosis is a rare distinct clinicopathological entity that can occur in isolation primary or in association with systemic autoimmune disorder secondary such a systemic lupus erythematosus and sjogrens syndrome this disease is characterized by isolated or combined chronic cytopenia associated with autoimmune phenomenon and bonemarrow fibrosis due to the rarity of this disease patient are frequently misdiagnosed a having primary myelofibrosis the most common form of bonemarrow fibrosis distinguishing between both disease entity is essential given the drastic therapeutic and prognostic difference between both disorder we report a case of primary autoimmune myelofibrosis presenting with severe isolated anemia refractory to multiple line of therapy this patient wa initially misdiagnosed a primary myelofibrosis the absence of the characteristic feature of primary myelofibrosis and the lack of a clonal abnormality on cytogenetic and molecular study particularly jak calr and mpl mutation analysis confirmed the absence of an aberrant neoplastic process furthermore the presence of monoclonal tcell receptor gamma gene rearrangement delineated the presence of an autoimmune disorder supporting our diagnosis of primary autoimmune myelofibrosis
label: Non-Cancer
combined_text: primary autoimmune myelofibrosis a case report and review of the literature autoimmune myelofibrosis is a rare distinct clinicopathological entity that can occur in isolation primary or in association with systemic autoimmune disorder secondary such a systemic lupus erythematosus and sjogrens syndrome this disease is characterized by isolated or combined chronic cytopenia associated with autoimmune phenomenon and bonemarrow fibrosis due to the rarity of this disease patient are frequently misdiagnosed a having primary myelofibrosis the most common form of bonemarrow fibrosis distinguishing between both disease entity is essential given the drastic therapeutic and prognostic difference between both disorder we report a case of primary autoimmune myelofibrosis presenting with severe isolated anemia refractory to multiple line of therapy this patient wa initially misdiagnosed a primary myelofibrosis the absence of the characteristic feature of primary myelofibrosis and the lack of a clonal abnormality on cytogenetic and molecular study particularly jak calr and mpl mutation analysis confirmed the absence of an aberrant neoplastic process furthermore the presence of monoclonal tcell receptor gamma gene rearrangement delineated the presence of an autoimmune disorder supporting our diagnosis of primary autoimmune myelofibrosis

title: pseudarthrosis repair using autologous cultured osteoblast in complex type neurofibromatosis spinal deformity a case report and review of the literature
abstract: study design a case report and literature review objective to report a late dislocation of the vertebra caused by progressive dural ectasia combined with type neurofibromatosis nf and the clinical result of pseudarthrosis repair using autologous cultured osteoblast summary of background data nf is a wellknown genetic disorder that is commonly characterized by spinal deformity including kyphoscoliosis late dislocation of the vertebra resulting from progressive dural ectasia after surgical correction of nf scoliosis is a very rare occurrence and pseudarthrosis frequently develops after surgical intervention for this complex spinal deformity method a yearold female patient with nf scoliosis underwent surgical correction with posterior instrumented fusion seventeen year later dislocation of the lumbar spine with implant failure resulting from massive progressive dural ectasia wa observed she underwent anterior interbody fusion three time and posterior instrumented fusion four time for pseudarthrosis followed by surgical deformity correction for the last operation autologous cultured osteoblast were used a a therapeutic approach to repair the pseudarthrosis and a threedimensional printing technique wa used to understand the surgical anatomy of the dislocated lumbar spine in detail result after the final operation bone union wa achieved and confirmed by clinical and radiological examination conclusion spine surgeon should be knowledgeable about the possibility of late destabilization of the spine due to pulsatile dural ectasia and a high rate of pseudarthrosis in neurofibromatosis autologous cultured osteoblast may prove to be a modality that can be applied pseudarthrosis repair to treat complex spinal deformity level of evidence
label: Non-Cancer

title: computational drug treatment simulation on projection of dysregulated protein network derived from the myelodysplastic mutanome match clinical response in patient
abstract: although the majority of md patient fail to achieve clinical improvement to approved therapy some patient benefit from treatment predicting patient response prior to therapy would improve treatment effectiveness avoid treatmentrelated adverse event and reduce healthcare cost three separate cohort of md patient were used to simulate drug response to lenalidomide alone hypomethylating agent hma alone or hma plus lenalidomide utilizing a computational biology program genomic abnormality in each patient were used to create an intracellular pathway map that wa then used to screen for drug response in the lenalidomide treated cohort computer modeling correctly matched clinical response in patient in the second cohort hma patient were modeled and correctly matched to response in in the third cohort computer modeling correctly matched response in patient this computational biology network approach identified ggh overexpression a a potential resistance factor to hma treatment and paradoxical activation of betacatenin through csnka inhibition a a resistance factor to lenalidomide treatment we demonstrate that a computational technology is able to map the complexity of the md mutanome to simulate and predict drug response this tool can improve understanding of md biology and mechanism of drug sensitivity and resistance
label: Non-Cancer

title: genetics meet pathology an increasingly important relationship
abstract: the analytical power of modern method for dna analysis ha outstripped our capability to interpret and understand the data generated to make good use of this genomic data in a biomedical setting whether for research or diagnosis it is vital that we understand the mechanism through which mutation affect biochemical pathway and physiological system this lie at the centre of what genetics is all about and it is the reason why genetics and genomics should go hand in hand whenever possible in this annual review issue of the journal of pathology we have assembled a collection of expert review covering a wide range of topic through these we illustrate the power of genetic analysis to improve our understanding of normal physiology and disease pathology and thereby to think in rational way about clinical management copyright pathological society of great britain and ireland published by john wiley son ltd
label: Non-Cancer

title: wiskottaldrich syndrome in a child presenting with macrothrombocytopenia
abstract: wiskottaldrich syndrome wa is a rare xlinked recessive disease resulting from variant in the wa gene characterized by a triad of immunodeficiency eczema and thrombocytopenia despite the fact that wa is traditionally differentiated from immune thrombocytopenia itp by small size of wa platelet in practice microthrombocytopenia may occasionally not be present and in certain case wa patient exhibit some parallelism to itp patient we characterized one patient presenting with the classic form of the disease but increased mean platelet volume molecular study revealed a novel hemizygous bp deletion in wa gene cdelc leading to a frameshift and stop codon at amino acid pargglyfs nextgeneration sequencing of a total of additional gene known to harbor variant implicated in inherited platelet disorder did not identify additional defect the pathogenesis of macrothrombocytopenia in this case is not known but probably the coexistence of a still unidentified additional genetic variant might be involved
label: Non-Cancer

title: quantification of atpb protein in dried blood spot by peptide immunosrm a a potential screen for wilson disease
abstract: wilson disease wd a copper transport disorder caused by a genetic defect in the atpb gene ha been a long time strong candidate for newborn screening nb since early intervention can give better result by preventing irreversible neurological disability or liver cirrhosis several previous pilot study measuring ceruloplasmin cp in infant or child showed that this marker alone wa insufficient to meet the universal screening for wd wd result from mutation that cause absent or markedly diminished level of atpb therefore atpb could serve a a marker for the screening of wd if the protein can be detected from dried blood spot db this study demonstrates that the immunosrm platform can quantify atpb in db in the picomolar range and that the assay readily distinguishes affected case from normal control p the assay precision wa cv and the protein wa stable for a week in db at room temperature these promising proofofconcept data open up the possibility of screening wd in newborn and the potential for a multiplexed assay for screening a variety of congenital disorder using protein a biomarkers in db
label: Non-Cancer

title: the mitotic checkpoint complex requires an evolutionary conserved cassette to bind and inhibit active apcc
abstract: the spindle assembly checkpoint sac ensures genomic stability by preventing sister chromatid separation until all chromosome are attached to the spindle it catalyzes the production of the mitotic checkpoint complex mcc which inhibits cdc to inactivate the anaphase promoting complexcyclosome apcc here we show that two cdcbinding motif in bubr of the recently identified abba motif class are crucial for the mcc to recognize active apcccdc mutating these motif eliminates mcc binding to the apcc thereby abolishing the sac and preventing cell from arresting in response to microtubule poison these abba motif flank a ken box to form a cassette that is highly conserved through evolution both in the arrangement and spacing of the abbakenabba motif and association with the aminoterminal ken box required to form the mcc we propose that the abbakenabba cassette hold the mcc onto the apcc by binding the two cdc molecule in the mccapcc complex
label: Non-Cancer

title: inferior vena cava filter
abstract: use of inferior vena cava ivc filter ha increased dramatically in recent decade despite a lack of evidence that their use ha impacted venous thromboembolism vterelated mortality this increased use appears to be primarily driven by the insertion of retrievable filter for prophylactic indication a growing body of evidence however suggests that ivc filter are frequently associated with clinically important adverse event prompting a closer look at their role we sought to narratively review the current evidence on the efficacy and safety of ivc filter placement inferior vena cava filter remain the only treatment option for patient with an acute within week proximal deep vein thrombosis dvt or pulmonary embolism and an absolute contraindication to anticoagulation in such patient anticoagulation should be resumed and ivc filter removed a soon a the contraindication ha passed for all other indication there is insufficient evidence to support the use of ivc filter and highquality trial are required in patient where an ivc filter remains regular followup to reassess removal and screen for filterrelated complication should occur
label: Non-Cancer
combined_text: inferior vena cava filter use of inferior vena cava ivc filter ha increased dramatically in recent decade despite a lack of evidence that their use ha impacted venous thromboembolism vterelated mortality this increased use appears to be primarily driven by the insertion of retrievable filter for prophylactic indication a growing body of evidence however suggests that ivc filter are frequently associated with clinically important adverse event prompting a closer look at their role we sought to narratively review the current evidence on the efficacy and safety of ivc filter placement inferior vena cava filter remain the only treatment option for patient with an acute within week proximal deep vein thrombosis dvt or pulmonary embolism and an absolute contraindication to anticoagulation in such patient anticoagulation should be resumed and ivc filter removed a soon a the contraindication ha passed for all other indication there is insufficient evidence to support the use of ivc filter and highquality trial are required in patient where an ivc filter remains regular followup to reassess removal and screen for filterrelated complication should occur

title: mutation in chromatin regulator functionally link cornelia de lange syndrome and clinically overlapping phenotype
abstract: the coordinated tissuespecific regulation of gene expression is essential for the proper development of all organism mutation in multiple transcriptional regulator cause a group of neurodevelopmental disorder termed transcriptomopathies that share core phenotypical feature including growth retardation developmental delay intellectual disability and facial dysmorphism cornelia de lange syndrome cdls belongs to this class of disorder and is caused by mutation in different subunit or regulator of the cohesin complex herein we report on the clinical and molecular characterization of seven patient with feature overlapping with cdls who were found to carry mutation in chromatin regulator previously associated to other neurodevelopmental disorder that are frequently considered in the differential diagnosis of cdls the identified mutation affect the methyltransferaseencoding gene kmta and setd and different subunit of the swisnf chromatinremodeling complex complementary to this a patient with coffinsiris syndrome wa found to carry a missense substitution in nipbl our finding indicate that mutation in a variety of chromatinassociated factor result in overlapping clinical phenotype underscoring the genetic heterogeneity that should be considered when assessing the clinical and molecular diagnosis of neurodevelopmental syndrome it is clear that emerging molecular mechanism of chromatin dysregulation are central to understanding the pathogenesis of these clinically overlapping genetic disorder
label: Non-Cancer

title: rare and lowfrequency coding variant alter human adult height
abstract: height is a highly heritable classic polygenic trait with approximately common associated variant identified through genomewide association study so far here we report heightassociated coding variant with lower minorallele frequency in the range of and effect of up to centimetre per allele such a those in ihh stc ar and crispld greater than ten time the average effect of common variant in functional followup study rare heightincreasing allele of stc giving an increase of centimetre per allele compromised proteolytic inhibition of pappa and increased cleavage of igfbp in vitro resulting in higher bioavailability of insulinlike growth factor these heightassociated variant overlap gene that are mutated in monogenic growth disorder and highlight new biological candidate such a adamts ilra and nox and pathway such a proteoglycan and glycosaminoglycan synthesis involved in growth our result demonstrate that sufficiently large sample size can uncover rare and lowfrequency variant of moderatetolarge effect associated with polygenic human phenotype and that these variant implicate relevant gene and pathway
label: Non-Cancer

title: a femoral common vein aneurysm in a patient with neurofibromatosis syndrome type
abstract: neurofibromatosis type i nfi also called von recklinghausen disease is an autosomal dominant disease secondary to a genetic mutation on the long arm of chromosome this disorder affect neural crest cell cutaneous clinical form are the most frequent with multiple benign skin neurofibroma associated with cafe au lait skin spot and iris hamartoma vascular abnormality in nf are rare but have also been well described the most frequent abnormality are characterized by arterial aneurysm degeneration stenosis and malformation venous location are rare but some case of venous aneurysm were described with rupture a complication we present a rare case of thrombosed venous femoral aneurysm associated with a pulmonary embolism in a patient affected by nf
label: Non-Cancer

title: mtorcindependent tfeb activation via akt inhibition promotes cellular clearance in neurodegenerative storage disease
abstract: neurodegenerative disease characterized by aberrant accumulation of undigested cellular component represent unmet medical condition for which the identification of actionable target is urgently needed here we identify a pharmacologically actionable pathway that control cellular clearance via akt modulation of transcription factor eb tfeb a master regulator of lysosomal pathway we show that akt phosphorylates tfeb at ser and represses tfeb nuclear translocation independently of mechanistic target of rapamycin complex mtorc a known tfeb inhibitor the autophagy enhancer trehalose activates tfeb by diminishing akt activity administration of trehalose to a mouse model of batten disease a prototypical neurodegenerative disease presenting with intralysosomal storage enhances clearance of proteolipid aggregate reduces neuropathology and prolongs survival of diseased mouse pharmacological inhibition of akt promotes cellular clearance in cell from patient with a variety of lysosomal disease thus suggesting broad applicability of this approach these finding open new perspective for the clinical translation of tfebmediated enhancement of cellular clearance in neurodegenerative storage disease
label: Non-Cancer

title: pegylated interferon alfaa in patient with essential thrombocythaemia or polycythaemia vera a posthoc median month followup of an openlabel phase trial
abstract: background pegylated interferon alfaa is an immunomodulatory agent used to treat polycythemia vera the durability of response and longterm safety of this drug in patient with polycythaemia vera and essential thrombocythaemia have not been reported here we present longterm efficacy and safety data from a singlecentre openlabel phase trial after a median of month follow up method patient older than year who were diagnosed with essential thrombocythaemia or polycythaemia vera according to who criterion were eligible to enrol in our study the initial starting dose of pegylated interferon alfaa wa mug subcutaneously once per week but wa decreased in a stepwise manner due to toxic effect to a final starting dose of mg per week three patient were started at a dose of mg per week three at mg per week at mg per week at mg per week and at mg per week treatment wa continued for a long a the patient derived clinical benefit with reduction in dose and frequency of administration allowed at the discretion of the treating physician haematological response were assessed every month on the basis of blood count a defined by the european leukemianet critieria the primary endpoint of the initial study wa the proportion of patient with a haematological response complete haematological response wa defined a normalisation of blood count for patient with essential thrombocythaemia platelet x per l for patient with polycythaemia vera haemoglobin gl without phlebotomy with complete resolution of palpable splenomegaly or symptom in the absence of a thrombotic event data were analysed with descriptive statistic and in the intentiontotreat population this study is registered with clinicaltrialsgov number nct and is ongoing but not enrolling new patient finding between may and dec patient were followed up for a median of month iqr month pegylated interferon alfaa induced haematological of patient and molecular response of patient in patient with essential thrombocythaemia and patient with polycythaemia vera with median duration of month iqr and month respectively of haematological responder and of molecular responder with the jak valphe mutation have maintained some response during followup maintained their best molecular response nine of ten patient who had a complete response five of who had a partial response and three of five who had a minor response the incidence of major venousthrombotic event during the study wa per personyears overall of patient discontinued therapy due to treatmentrelated toxicity although toxicity rate decreased over time five patient had treatmentlimiting grade or toxicity after month on therapy patient are still enrolled on the study interpretation pegylated interferon alfaa can induce durable haematological and molecular response in patient with essential thrombocythaemia and polycythaemia vera this drug alone and in combination with other drug could be explored further in clinical trial funding u national cancer institute

title: enlarged posterior fossa on prenatal imaging differential diagnosis associated anomaly and postnatal outcome
abstract: introduction the primary aim of this study wa to ascertain the prevalence of the individual condition and of associated anomaly in fetus with the prenatal diagnosis of enlarged posterior fossa pf and to explore the diagnostic accuracy of ultrasound in these anomaly the secondary aim wa to evaluate the postnatal outcome of child affected by pf anomaly material and method all fetus with enlarged pf detected by prenatal sonography at a referral center from to were analyzed retrospectively some were also studied by fetal magnetic resonance imaging mri or volume ultrasound examination fetal sonographic and mri were compared using following classification dandywalker malformation dwm megacisterna magna mcm blake pouch cyst isolated vermian hypoplasia vermian agenesis pf arachnoid cyst ac and cerebellar hypoplasia ch result the ultrasound diagnosis of the fetus were a follows mcm n of these isolated n dwm n isolated n vermian hypoplasia n isolated n blake pouch cyst n isolated n ch n none isolated and ac in the pf n isolated thirteen of the karyotyped fetus were aneuploid including seven with dwm associated malformation were found in case there were live birth including with confirmed dwm six of whom show a normal development twelve infant with isolated mcm show normal development there were eight falsepositive prenatal diagnosis or resolution until birth of enlarged pf three with blake pouch cyst two with mcm and one with vermian hypoplasia conclusion an enlarged pf requires specific diagnosis for the best possible counseling the term dandywalker variant should not be used anymore isolated mcm and blake pouch cyst can either resolve or be normal variant but may also indicate the presence of a more severe anomaly or associated malformation
label: Non-Cancer

title: staged induction of hiv glycandependent broadly neutralizing antibody
abstract: a preventive hiv vaccine should induce hivspecific broadly neutralizing antibody bnabs however bnabs generally require high level of somatic hypermutation shm to acquire breadth and current vaccine strategy have not been successful in inducing bnabs because bnabs directed against a glycosylated site adjacent to the third variable loop v of the hiv envelope protein require limited shm the vglycan epitope is an attractive vaccine target by studying the cooperation among multiple vglycan b cell lineage and their coevolution with autologous virus throughout year of infection we identify key event in the ontogeny of a vglycan bnab two autologous neutralizing antibody lineage selected for virus escape mutation and consequently allowed initiation and affinity maturation of a vglycan bnab lineage the nucleotide substitution required to initiate the bnab lineage occurred at a lowprobability site for activationinduced cytidine deaminase activity cooperation of b cell lineage and an improbable mutation critical for bnab activity defined the necessary event leading to breadth in this vglycan bnab lineage these finding may in part explain why initiation of vglycan bnabs is rare and suggest an immunization strategy for inducing similar vglycan bnabs
label: Non-Cancer

title: wholeexome sequencing and digital pcr identified a novel compound heterozygous mutation in the nphp gene in a case of joubert syndrome and related disorder
abstract: background joubert syndrome and related disorder jsrd is a clinically and genetically heterogeneous condition with autosomal recessive or xlinked inheritance which share a distinctive neuroradiological hallmark the socalled molar tooth sign jsrd is classified into six clinical subtypes based on associated variable multiorgan involvement to date causative gene have been identified in jsrd which make genetic diagnosis difficult case presentation we report here a case of a yearold japanese woman diagnosed with j with oculorenal defect with a novel compound heterozygous mutation pserdeletion in the nphp gene wholeexome sequencing wes of the patient identified the novel nonsense mutation in an apparently homozygous state however it wa absent in her mother and heterozygous in her father a read depthbased copy number variation cnv detection algorithm using wes data of the family predicted a large heterozygous deletion mutation in the patient and her mother which wa validated by digital polymerase chain reaction indicating that the patient wa compound heterozygous for the paternal nonsense mutation and the maternal deletion mutation spanning the site of the single nucleotide change conclusion it should be noted that analytical pipeline that focus purely on sequence information can not distinguish homozygosity from hemizygosity because of it inability to detect large deletion the ability to detect cnvs in addition to single nucleotide variant and small insertiondeletions make wes an attractive diagnostic tool for genetically heterogeneous disorder
label: Non-Cancer

title: legius syndrome a case report
abstract: legius syndrome is a rare genetic disorder caused by heterozygous germ line lossoffunction spred mutation in japan a family with legius syndrome wa first described in by sakai et al we described a first solitary case of legius syndrome identified by nextgeneration sequencing in japan a yearold woman presented with multiple cafeaulait macule and freckle but ha no other feature of neurofibromatosis type nf sequencing result showed the presence of a mutation in exon of spred cct resulting in the protein at position pargx when a dermatological clinician see an adult patient showing only pigmented lesion and no other specifically diagnostic feature of nf it is important to suspect the possibility of legius syndrome
label: Non-Cancer

title: oligodendrocyte nf control aberrant notch activation and regulates myelin structure and behavior
abstract: the rasopathy neurofibromatosis type nf is one of the most common autosomal dominant genetic disorder in nf patient neurological issue may result from damaged myelin and mouse with a neurofibromin gene nf mutation show white matter wm defect including myelin decompaction using mouse genetics we find that altered nf genedose in mature oligodendrocyte result in progressive myelin defect and behavioral abnormality mediated by aberrant notch activation blocking notch upstream mitogenactivated protein kinase mapk or nitric oxide signaling rescue myelin defect in hemizygous nf mutant and pharmacological gamma secretase inhibition rescue aberrant behavior with no effect in wildtype wt mouse concomitant pathway inhibition rescue myelin abnormality in homozygous mutant notch activation is also observed in nf mouse brain and cell containing active notch are increased in nf patient wm we thus identify notch a an nf effector regulating myelin structure and behavior in a rasopathy and suggest that inhibition of notch signaling may be a therapeutic strategy for nf
label: Non-Cancer

title: assessment of the interlaboratory variability and robustness of jakvf mutation assay a study involving a consortium of italian laboratory
abstract: to date a plenty of technique for the detection of jakvf is used over different laboratory with substantial difference in specificity and sensitivity therefore to provide reliable and comparable result the standardization of molecular technique is mandatorya network of center wa established to evaluate the inter and intralaboratory variability in jakvf quantification identify the most robust assay for the standardization of the molecular test and allow consistent interpretation of individual patient analysis result the study wa conceived in different round in which all center had to blindly test dna sample with different jakvf allele burden ab using both quantitative and qualitative assaysthe positivity of sample with an ab wa not detected by qualitative assay conversely laboratory performing the quantitative approach were able to determine the expected jakvf ab quantitative result were reliable across all mutation load with moderate variability at low ab and cv and respectively remarkably all laboratory clearly distinguished between the and mutated samplesin conclusion a qualitative approach is not sensitive enough to detect the jakvf mutation especially at low ab on the contrary the ipsogen jak mutaquant ceivd kit resulted in a high efficient and sensitive quantification detection of all mutation load this study set the basis for the standardization of molecular technique for jakvf determination which will require the employment of approved operating procedure and the use of certificated standard such a the recent who st international reference panel for genomic jakvf
label: Non-Cancer

title: aneurysm in neurofibromatosis type evidence for vasculopathy
abstract: there have been anecdotal report of vasculopathy associated with neurofibromatosis type nf given the increasing use of bevacizumab a vascular endothelial growth factor inhibitor which result in an increased risk of bleeding it is important to ascertain if there is a predisposition to vascular abnormality in nf in our unit nf patient undergo annual mri brain and internal auditory meatus imaging we noted incidental intracranial aneurysm in some patient and sought to determine the prevalence of intracranial aneurysm in our cohort of nf patient we conducted a retrospective audit of the mri image of nf patient from to axial t brain mri image were assessed for vascular abnormality by two neuroradiologists blinded to patient clinical detail intracranial aneurysm were detected in four patient and an aneurysm clip related to previous surgery wa noted in one additional patient using standard mri imaging sequence alone we provide evidence of intracranial aneurysm in of our cohort this compare with an estimated overall prevalence of in the general population we discus these finding a well a other evidence for a vasculopathy associated with nf
label: Non-Cancer

title: prospective evaluation of the diagnostic value of sensitive kit dv mutation analysis of blood in adult with suspected systemic mastocytosis
abstract: background sensitive kit dv mutation analysis of blood ha been proposed to guide bone marrow bm investigation in suspected systemic mastocytosis sm the aim of this prospective study wa for the first time to compare the dv status of the screening blood sample used to guide bm biopsy in suspected sm to the outcome of the subsequent bm investigation method fiftyeight adult patient with suspected sm were included the outcome of sensitive kit dv analysis of blood wa compared to the result of the bm investigation result screening blood sample from of patient tested dvpositive in of these sm wa subsequently diagnosed in the bm investigation one patient with a dvpositive screening sample wa diagnosed with monoclonal mc activation syndrome screening blood sample from patient tested dvnegative sm wa subsequently diagnosed in five of these whereas nine patient did not fulfill any diagnostic sm criterion excluding tryptase criterion of the sm patient tested dvpositive thirteen sm patient presented with hymenoptera venominduced anaphylaxis no skin lesion and baseline serum tryptase ngml of these tested dvpositive in the screening blood sample conclusion this prospective study demonstrates that a dvpositive result in a screening blood sample identifies sm among patient with hymenoptera venominduced anaphylaxis in whom the diagnosis would most probably have been missed with potential severe implication the observed falsenegative screening result also underline that bm investigation is mandatory in all adult patient with clear sign of or highly suspected sm regardless of the kit mutation status
label: Non-Cancer
